description: The specific institutional conditions in 1936 Britain caused inflation to work as intended once, and not well. Stimulus policy today completely ignores these origins and has become a universal solvent to heal all economic ills.

title: The G7's Reckless Commitment To Mounting Debt
description: The global minimum tax rate will not hurt G7 members or large technology giants, but it will devastate small and dynamic countries that need to attract capital and investment and who cannot afford to have the tax rate of global leading nations.

title: Is Guaranteed Basic Income the Solution to Robots Taking Our Jobs?
description: The automation doomers assume that when jobs are eliminated by automation in one place, that the number of jobs are permanently gone. For this to be true, there would have to be no growth in the need for labor elsewhere.

title: A Brief History of Secession Referenda in Europe
description: Over the past 200 years, Europeans have held many elections to decide secession questions. In some cases, these votes were used in the creation of an entirely new sovereign state.

title: Why America's Oligarchs Are Moving Left
description: Wokeness may now be a public relations strategy—a method of appealing to the moral sensibilities of the upper-middle-class woke American consumer.

title: With Reverse Repos, The Fed Is Now Trying to Clean up Its Own Mess
description: One of the areas of the economy that the Fed recently needed to bail out was money market funds. Most investors consider these funds cash. One wonders why the Fed would be forced to provide liquidity to shore up liquidity.

title: Much Ado about Nothing in the Art Market
description: The recent sale of an invisible statue for £13,000 is symptomatic of the thoroughgoing financialization of our economy. Investors have become ever more obsessed with the symbols of economic reality and less concerned with underlying economic facts.

title: Texas Says It Can Enforce Immigration Restrictions. Texas Is Right
description: However one may feel about immigrants, both historical experience and an honest reading of the US Constitution makes it clear that the federal government is not, in fact, empowered to enforce immigration.

title: Bitcoin's El Salvador Option
description: If Bukele really wants monetary freedom for El Salvador, he should not have presented them with what, effectively, is a government handout for bitcoin hodlers and the companies behind the Strike app and other potential intermediaries.

title: Why the US Supports Secession for Africans, but Not for Americans
description: The United States has long supported the idea of secession and "self-determination" for some faraway colonies. But the US regime is careful to define self-determination so as to deny any chance of secession closer to home.

title: Why Keynes Was Wrong about Unemployment
description: Henry Hazlitt’s second law is the observation that everything in Keynes's General Theory is either unoriginal or untrue. Keynes's theory of unemployment equilibrium is the most original aspect of his work.

title: With Capitalism, Cooperation Is Just as Important as Competition
description: Free consumers and business owners always seek to cooperate in the marketplace. After all, "suppose there were no coming together, each individual dependent solely on his or her own thoughts and productivity…. All would starve!"

title: How the Federalists Stacked the Deck to Win Ratification
description: The Federalists employed all the tricks: from delaying the postal delivery of Antifederalists' pamphlets to waging a propaganda war in the press. The Federalists also did their best to limit suffrage only to groups likely to vote for ratification.

title: Why Monetary "Stimulus" Won't Prevent an Economic Bust
description: If the Fed were to embark on aggressive monetary pumping to counter economic recession this will not produce the intended effect. It will only dilute the pool of real savings and make things worse.

title: How the Federalists Stacked the Deck to Win Ratification
description: The Federalists employed all the tricks: from delaying the postal delivery of Antifederalists' pamphlets to waging a propaganda war in the press. The Federalists also did their best to limit suffrage only to groups likely to vote for ratification.

title: Without Sound Economics, the Progressives Win
description: Many subscribe to the mistaken belief that the facts speak for themselves, that experience and common sense by themselves can explode false interpretations. The march of Progressivism has proven this fanciful idea wrong.

title: Guatemala: The Human Rights Nightmare That Is the US Drug War
description: Biden's plan to give more money to Central American regimes will do nothing to compensate farmers, businessmen, and others still victimized by the US war on drugs.

title: "Supply Bottlenecks" as an Excuse for Inflation
description: First, money is aggressively printed with the excuse that “there is no inflation.” When inflation rises, central banks and governments tell us that it is “transitory” or due to “multicausal” effects.

title: How Defamation Suits Are Used to Stifle Free Speech
description: There is no place in a free society for a government that sues private citizens for defamation. But even between private parties, defamation suits are often used by the powerful to silence others.

title: What They Must Learn Now
description: Mises University offers students a radical alternative: a week where civilization and truth reassert themselves. In addition to Austrian economics, they receive a grounding in the foundations of a free society, from property and markets to social cooperation to peace.

title: Why "Wild Swings" in Crypto Prices Are Not Really a Problem
description: Price "stability" has never been a feature of a free marketplace.  Stability is an obsession of central banks, and the day may come when central bankers intervene to "stabilize" crypto prices. That will be a bad thing.

title: Why Corporate Lobbyists and Special Interest Groups Won't Go Away
description: Today, the political system really is in many ways what H.L. Mencken suggested when he described elections as a sort of "advance auction of stolen goods." The only answer lies in reducing the number of stolen goods available.

title: How Marriage Patterns May Have Helped Fuel Europe's Rise to Wealth
description: Many factors help explain the rise of the West, including both decentralization and the embrace of laissez-faire. But Europe's unusual pattern of family formation is also a likely and important factor.

title: The Origins of Keynesian Economics: How Did It Get So Popular?
description: Keynes's early critics repeatedly demolished Keynes's theories, pointing  out countless fallacies behind the so-called "new economics." Yet Keynes and his theories only gained in popularity. Why?

title: New York Politicians Have No Idea How to Fix the Subways
description: New York City subways are in deep financial trouble and the quality of service is in a downward spiral. Yet even talking about privatization is verboten.

title: How Facebook Turned Its Market Success into a Culture War on America
description: Corporate America—from Facebook to Google to Major League Baseball—got rich by giving the consumers what they want. Now these big firms will use their riches to crush their ideological enemies. That's life in a "mixed economy."

title: A Libertarian Approach to Disputed Land Titles
description: Rothbard gives us the rough foundation of justice, but only common law juries—temporalized and local—can fill in the gaps.

title: Canadian Secession: Then and Now
description: Just as Canada had the right to secede from Britain, so too do the provinces and territories have a right to secede from Canada. Today, secession may be Alberta’s remedy against the Canadian regime's abuses.

title: The Fed's Policies since the 2020 Coronavirus Panic
description: Since the corona panic, the Fed has bought a ton of government bonds, but it's also started buying corporate bonds, has abolished reserve requirements, redefined their M1 measure, and switched to average inflation targeting.

title: Entrepreneurs Are Motivated by Profit, Not Risk
description: A capitalist never chooses that investment in which, according to his understanding of the future, the danger of losing his input is smallest. He chooses that investment in which he expects to make the highest possible profits.

title: The Abuse of Public Debt—and How It Sets the Stage for Economic Disaster
description: The majority of economists, who assume recent historical trends will continue forever, forget that nonlinearity in economics means that cause-and-effect relationships can remain dormant for a long time, only to manifest themselves with unusual force later on.

title: Private Security Isn't Enough: Why America Needs Militias
description: Private security tends to provide its services to the highest bidder. And you know that almost always ends up being the regime itself. Corn farmers just can’t cut the same kinds of checks that tax farmers can.

title: The Case of Joe Rogan: Vaccine Policy and Freedom of Speech
description: For politically "sensitive" subjects, authorities do not accept deviations from their official story. This deleterious situation has existed since long before the pandemic.

title: Why Are Progressives Obsessed with the Transgender Policies at the College of the Ozarks?
description: Anyone considering going to the very conservative College of the Ozarks knows what he's getting into. Yet the Biden administration has launched a war on this tiny college in the name of "equality" for transgendered students who have no reason to ever set foot there.

title: Private Security Apps May Be the Future of Neighborhood Policing
description: We're beginning to see some early attempts by private firms to provide simple, affordable private security beyond wealthy or corporate clients.

title: Economic Cannibalism Will Not Save Mexico, or Any Other Country
description: It seems absurd to have to point out that economic cannibalism, even in the face of a virus, cannot produce anything but devastation, but alas, we live in absurd times.

title: The Worst-Kept Secret in America: High Inflation Is Back
description: From wood to copper to corn, prices for basic necessities for both production and consumption are rising to multiyear highs. The Fed says it has everything under control, but the Fed has a terrible track record in both predictions and executing its plans.

title: America Still Loves the Warfare State
description: The difficulty Trump encountered in trying to even slightly scale back American military schemes shows just how far Americans are from abandoning the idea that the United States is the indispensable nation entitled to fight wars always and everywhere.

title: Decentralization: Why the EU May Be Better Than the US
description: It's too late for American member states to assert real independence from the central government without facing an avalanche of legal, political, and even military opposition. Europeans would be wise to not put themselves in a similar position.

title: More Evidence the American Economic "Recovery" Will Disappoint
description: Two things should concern us. First, the weakness of the recovery in the middle of the largest fiscal and monetary stimulus seen in decades, and second, the short and diminishing effect of these programs.

title: There's No Conflict Between Profit and "Social Responsibility"
description: The "People over Profits" mantra is once again is being heard in Washington. But this time we're hearing about it from business lobbyists themselves who are now parroting leftwing slogans about "social responsibility."

title: Why Economic Models Can't Provide a Realistic Picture of Human Behavior
description: Mises: "The experience with which the sciences of human action have to deal is always an experience of complex phenomena. No laboratory experiments can be performed with regard to human action."

title: Forget Hemlines. Mom Jeans Are Now an Economic Indicator.
description: Many have long speculated that there is a correlation between economic prosperity and the length of women's hemlines. But perhaps it's now "mom jeans," with their high waists and ample fit, that indicate the true state of the economy.

title: Why Economic Models Can't Provide a Realistic Picture of Human Behavior
description: Mises: "The experience with which the sciences of human action have to deal is always an experience of complex phenomena. No laboratory experiments can be performed with regard to human action."

title: The Bogus January 6 Commission Poses a Real Threat to Freedom
description: Biden and congressional Democrats are seeking to turbocharge their push for a new domestic terrorism law to permit widespread federal crackdowns on their opponents. Any rigged commission would likely pour gasoline on a fire that could singe far more American rights and liberties.

title: China's New Pandemic: A Bond Default Crisis
description: As the world’s second-largest economy attempts to return to its precrisis glory days, Beijing could potentially deal with a new pandemic that could have a sweeping effect on financial markets at home and abroad: a bond default crisis.

title: How the Constitutional Convention Vastly Expanded the Powers of the President
description: After centralizing political power in the presidency to a level unfathomable to most Americans, the nationalists had succeeded, and the new Constitution was ready to be sprung upon an unsuspecting country.

title: Why Cause-of-Death Stats Aren't as Reliable as the CDC Wants You to Think
description: Like any other piece of aggregate government data, cause-of-death data is used to justify new government interventions and policies. But there are good reasons to suspect there are many problems in compiling and auditing this data.

title: Public Debt Got a Lot Worse from the Great Recession to the Great Lockdown
description: Debt accumulation was already unsustainable prior to 2020, but the Great Lockdown has triggered an explosive increase. It may soon be reaching a point of no return for the world's major economies.

title: What Igbo Culture Teaches Us about Capitalism
description: The Igbo ethnic group in Africa is known for entrepreneurship, economic success, and a high degree of individualism. The group's cultural background can help us understand how culture and capitalism reinforce each other.

title: Biden's Jobs Plan: More Government Jobs Won't Fix the Economy
description: Government jobs may help reduce the official unemployment rate, but they actually damage the economy. After all, most government workers are employed in the business of redistributing wealth and regulating private property.

title: Monetary and Fiscal "Stimulus" Is Undermining the Global Recovery
description: Today’s calls for a plethora of new government stimulus polices to usher in a "recovery" will only cripple efforts by investors and entrepreneurs to get the global economy back on track.

title: Mises on Nationalism, Colonialism, and the Right of Self-Determination
description: Mises argues that the nation has a fundamental and relatively permanent being independent of the transient state (or states) which may govern it at any given time. Thus he refers to the nation as “an organic entity [which] can be neither increased nor reduced by changes in states.”

title: Why the Misuse of the Word "Efficiency" Is Such a Problem
description: "Efficiency" has largely been demoted from a useful term of analysis and insight to little more than another warning that the government is about to rip you off with another redistribution scheme.

title: Do Austrians "Hate Math"?
description: Quantitative methods are indeed useful and enlightening in the fields of economic history and descriptive economics. For Mises, however, these fields do not fall within the field of economics, narrowly understood.

title: Does Bitcoin Use "Too Much" Electricity?
description: Elizabeth Warren has decided that bitcoin mining uses "too much" electricity. This raises an important question: Is Senator Warren qualified to decide on the "correct" amount of electricity usage?

title: Let's Level the Playing Field between the Dollar and Competing Currencies
description: Thanks to so many government restrictions on the use of potential monies that aren’t the dollar, we can only guess as to what the relationship between dollars and bitcoin would be in a functioning marketplace. But it doesn't have to be that way.

title: Inflation Is Great If You're Already Rich
description: We've seen pictures of empty shelves in Venezuela. Meantime, the one-year return on the Caracas stock exchange is 1,804.92 percent. If you're already rich in assets, inflation is a big nothing burger. But it's a problem if you're poor.

title: What Does "Seasonally Adjusted" Mean?
description: Without a coherent theory, it is not possible to begin to understand the causes of business cycle and no amount of data torturing by means of the most advanced mathematical methods will do the trick.

title: How Covid Put an End to Your Right to Due Process
description: The covid panic brought an end to due process in many ways. Among these are the end of speedy trials and the end of a timely hearing for landlords to obtain evictions. Meanwhile, governments have seized private businesses with no due process at all.

title: Investors Won't Buy the "Transitory" Inflation Line
description: Governments always justify printing more money with the excuse that there is no inflation. When inflation rises, they say it is transitory. And when inflation soars, governments blame businesses and shop owners, presenting themselves as the solution with “price controls.”

title: The New Constitution: The Ratification and Amendment Process
description: The founders of the new constitution proposed a cynical end run around state legislatures in order to improve the odds of ratification.  The "founding fathers" increasingly abandoned established law, justifying it with claims of a "national emergency."

title: Money-Supply Growth Finally Slows in March, Drops to 10-Month Low
description: During March 2021, year-over-year (YOY) growth in the money supply was at 34.1 percent. That's down slightly from February's rate of 39.1 percent, and up from the March 2020 rate of 11.3 percent.

title: The Real Estate Boom in Vegas Is More Frenzied Than Ever
description: In Las Vegas, asset price inflation is combining with rising prices on building materials to create a real estate bubble of remarkable proportions.

title: How Monetary Expansion Creates Income and Wealth Inequality
description: Economic inequality caused by money printing benefits most those who claim to stand up for "the little guy" and denounce "trickle-down" markets. But there is nothing more "trickle down" than government money printing from on high.

title: Biden Wants a Global Minimum Tax to Offset His Proposed Huge Corporate Tax Increase
description: Raising the US corporate tax would drive more capital out of the US. But the tax hike will be less risky if the US can get other countries to raise their tax rates as well.

title: "Infrastructure" Is Now Anything the Government Wants to Do
description: Just as SJWs redefined justice as "social justice"—with big implications for how we view true justice—politicians are redefining infrastructure to justify even more government intervention in daily life.

title: Yes, Paul Krugman, Booms Are Unsustainable
description: Austrians do not question booms because they don’t like prosperity or because they have character defects. Rather, Austrians understand that booms involve lines of investment in areas of production that cannot be sustained.

title: These European Countries Beat Poverty and Increased Wealth with Low Taxes and Low Regulation
description: Social democrats love to denounce low-tax, probusiness regimes as "neoliberal" and as places with more poverty. But the reality is that parts of Europe that embraced markets most reduced poverty while making their citizens richer.

title: Vaccine Passports and Medical Paternalism
description: The world's regimes have long been devoted to regulating every aspect of "health" in accordance with what central planners want. The covid panic offered them an opportunity to greatly expand these powers.

title: The US Government Is On Track to Top Last Year's Record-Breaking Deficits
description: The deficit for the year is pushing $2 trillion. And we still have five months to go until the end of the fiscal year. Only during World War II were the deficits so huge in relation to GDP. Meanwhile, the Fed continues to print money to buy more Federal debt.

title: There's No Reprieve in Sight from the "Monetary Repression Tax"
description: There is nothing new in a fiat-money central bank imposing an effective tax on the public’s holdings of government debt by manipulating interest rates. But few thought it could go on this long.

title: The Dystopian Future in Which Almost No One Owns a Car
description: Some advocates of self-driving cars argue that their adoption would mean that very few people would actually own a vehicle anymore. We'd all just rent rides on self-driving Uber cars. This would be a dream come true for advocates of lockdowns and stay-at-home orders.

title: Why Fungibility Is Important in Understanding Money and Crypto
description: One of the most in-demand aspects of physical cash is that it is totally fungible. Every dollar is the same as every dollar. But cryptocurrencies can leave a digital trail which may lead to later problems in fungibility.

title: Boom to Bust: How Inflation Turns into Deflation
description: Seemingly endless amounts of fiscal and monetary stimulus will keep prices rising in the near term. But if the banking sector and other bubble industries weaken, we will eventually see deflation as new loan activity lessens.

title: The Media Wants You to Trust Washington Again Now That Trump Is Gone
description: Perhaps reporter Michelle Kosinski is unaware that the Trump-era secrecy she denounced flourished mightily thanks to the beloved Obama administration. Kosinski’s mindset also helps explain why Americans' trust in the media has collapsed.

title: Covid Deaths Plummet as Excess Mortality Falls to Precovid Levels
description: By mid March—when barely 12 percent of the population had been vaccinated—total excess mortality was back within 1 percent of 2019 levels. In other words, the number of deaths in the US is collapsing back to where it was before the official start of the pandemic.

title: 3 Ways the Tech Oligarchs' New Subsidy Is Ripping You Off
description: When it comes to the oligarchs' new semiconductor subsidy scheme, the real cost in terms of economic distortions, lost welfare, and harm to competitors, is quite real and beyond the dollar amounts we see in the subsidy itself.

title: Babbitt Is Back
description: The people selling us democracy believe in it the same way George F. Babbitt believes in a new listing from the Babbitt-Thompson Realty Company.

title: Biden's Family Leave Is Yet Another Attack on the Family
description: Only a bureaucrat would assume that putting a small child in public school is just as effective as keeping the child at home with a parent. Unfortunately for Biden, the research isn’t on his side.

title: We Cannot Build an Economy on Lies
description: American journalists and academics have invented a fairy tale in which "free market orthodoxy" has dominated political thinking in America for the past forty years. This is not even slightly true, but pundits repeat the lie again and again.

title: Washington's Bipartisan Fiscal Folly
description: Donald Trump—despite adopting a number of economically intelligent policies—was completely unwilling to rein in federal spending. Then things got even worse.

title: Keynes Thought Scarcity Would Disappear in the Near Future. Boy, Was He Wrong.
description: It is not surprising that Keynes looks at the economy from the perspective of a government bureaucrat; this is exactly what, for a significant part of his life, he was. It was for his bureaucratic "service," not his economics, that he was elevated to the peerage.

title: An Autoethnographic Account of the Free Market: My Father
description: Autoethnographies place the self within a social, historical context. In this one, Michael Rectenwald approaches the free market from the standpoint of his own experience.

title: Self-Interest versus Racial Solidarity
description: Modern-day race theories—much like the standard racist theories of the past—assume that racial solidarity ought to be the overriding factor in all human behavior. Experience shows this is not at all always the case.

title: An American Classical Liberalism
description: Today's conflicts revolve around the desire to grab hold of someone else's property using the tool of compulsion that is the state. Would we be more peaceful and prosperous if it followed the liberal program? The question answers itself.

title: Due Process on Campus Keeps Justice on the Streets
description: The reality in colleges today becomes reality on the streets tomorrow. The privileged treatment of women under Title IX has had profound implications for campus sexual misconduct hearings that threaten due process for all.

title: Three Reasons Why the Biden Tax Increase Makes No Sense
description: Biden’s tax increase plan does not make sense from a growth, revenue, or deficit perspective, and it does virtually nothing to address the real problem: ballooning spending on programs like Social Security.

title: The Fed Embraces Its Inner Zimbabwean
description: With Jerome Powell and Janet Yellen focusing on using monetary policy to manage climate change, the M1 money supply has gone parabolic, from just over $4 trillion in February to $18.6 trillion in March. This is right out of Zimbabwe's playbook.

title: Monetary Pumping and Idle Resources
description: A loose monetary policy that is aimed at boosting use of idle resources won't work. Idle resources only become profitable and efficient when we have enough real savings. Unfortunately, easy money policies destroy real savings.

title: What Happens When Governments Force Corporate Boards to Appoint More Women
description: Recent legislation in California mandates more women on corporate boards. This is supposed to shift the balance in corporate America in favor of female employees and managers. It doesn't seem to be working.

title: Decentralization, Absolutism, and the Papal States
description: The Papal States offer a helpful case study in understanding the transformation of Europe in the nineteenth century. Unfortunately, Kertzer's study on the topic is couched in faulty notions of enlightenment and medievalism.

title: The Ruling Class Only Cares about Democracy When It Helps Them
description: Democracy is only acceptable when the outcome is what the ruling class wants. Fortunately, the federal courts are always handy to overturn the results of free elections.

title: Why Is There No Correlation between Masks, Lockdowns, and Covid Suppression?
description: Those who demand government-enforced lockdowns and mask mandates still can't seem to explain why we still can't find a correlation between lockdowns and covid infections or between mask wearing and mask mandates.

title: The Ruling Class Only Cares about Democracy When It Helps Them
description: Democracy is only acceptable when the outcome is what the ruling class wants. Fortunately, the federal courts are always handy to overturn the results of free elections.

title: The Dark Side of Yield Curve Control Policy
description: The interest control policy is ultimately an admission of “fiscal dominance.” That is, it is increasingly difficult to deny that the state's budget situation is what dictates monetary policy. Now, monetary policy must first serve the interests of the regime itself.

title: The "Miracle Recovery" Narrative: We'll Just Print Our Way to Prosperity
description: With a new round of panic-induced lockdowns, the situation in Europe is one closely resembling a state of national emergency. Yet the official narrative tells us the European economy is robust and flourishing. Time for a reality check.

title: How Trillions in Newly Printed Money Created a Labor Shortage
description: The US has millions of idle workers. In a normal economy this would put a damper on demand. But in our money-printing economy, consumer demand is surging even as production falls behind. An employment bubble is the result.

title: No, Conservatives Should Not Embrace MMT
description: Instead of trying to spin conservative justifications for disastrous monetary policy, conservatives should join libertarians and classical liberals in working to limit government power while restoring sound money and greater market freedom.

title: The American Rescue Plan: Limits of the Highly Visible
description: In the long run, economic stimulus creates no shortage of losers. The state’s objective is always to extract as many eggs from the golden goose as possible, only now it's not important to keep the goose alive.

title: Lord Acton: Libertarian Hero
description: When some years ago I first read Murray Rothbard's description of Lord Acton as "the great Catholic libertarian historian," I suspected overstatement. The more I learned from and about Acton, however, the more Rothbard's words rang true.

title: The Fundamental Economic Problem with Biden's Rescue Plan
description: Do huge wealth redistribution schemes like Biden's new plan actually make people better off? Some people will get a net benefit. How how numerous are they? How many millions will take a net loss? The government has no idea.

title: Milton Friedman's Methodological Mistake
description: Key methodological differences between Austrians were highlighted in Milton Friedman's "The Methodology of Positive Economics." A key piece of conflict: Friedman's focus on prediction rather than explanation.

title: Tobacco Smokers: America's Most Persecuted Minority
description: If today they come for the smoker, tomorrow they will come for you. Neo-Prohibitionism has been long on the march.

title: Vengeance and Sacrifice: Whiteness as Scapegoat in Critical Race Theory and Critical Whiteness Studies
description: The ideas of critical race theory and critical white studies shield a ruling elite from vengeance by attempting to make the mass of white people the scapegoat for their own crimes.

title: Local Nullification: A Way to Fight Both State and Federal Despots
description: Local nullification offers a practical guide to resisting tyranny in a way that reflects the real wishes of local community members against the ivory-tower mentality of their government “representatives.”

title: How Markets Have Delivered More Economic Equality
description: People must still compete for resources in a socialist economy. In fact, the competition is intense. On the other hand, thanks to markets, basic necessities—and even basic luxuries—are now more more accessible than ever.

title: Monetary Savings versus Real Savings
description: What matters for real economics is real savings, not increases in consumer spending driven by money printing. The best way to get an increase in savings is to decrease both money pumping and government spending.

title: The Debate over the Scope of National Power
description: The nationalists at the Constitutional Convention had so far carried the substance of their program: the creation of a supreme national government and a Congress empowered to veto state laws whenever Congress thought the states "incompetent."

title: An Austrian Critique of Robert Mundell's "Impossible Trinity"
description: The impossibility theorem, developed by Nobel-winning economist Robert Mundell, paints a false tradeoff between the free movement of capital, fixed exchange rates, and effective monetary policy. Under a gold standard, all three are a possibility.

title: It's Time to End the Embargo against Cuba
description: Now that Cuban president Raul Castro has resigned the presidency of Cuba, will the US government lift its six-decade economic embargo against Cuba? Don't bet on it.

title: Patriotism
description: “When men hire themselves out to shoot other men to order, asking nothing about the justice of their cause, I don’t care if they are shot themselves.”

title: Thanks to the Fed, the High-Risk, Small-Time Borrower Is Becoming a Thing of the Past
description: The central bank has basically destroyed the business of risk, and commercial real estate remains a looming disaster. As a result, banks aren't lending to regular people. The economy increasingly relies on little more than newly printed money.

title: Why Empowering Organized Labor Will Definitely Not Help the Economy
description: Contrary to what Krugman might argue, the growth of organized labor in the US workforce was much more the work of government prodding and outright coercion than it was a natural progression of the American workplace.

title: The US Recovery Is Weak, Especially Given the Size of the "Stimulus"
description: It seems that governments want to convince us that they have saved the world when the reality is that the misguided lockdowns were the cause of the economic debacle and lifting them is the main cause of the recovery.

title: No, Dogecoin Does Not Compete with Bitcoin
description: Medium of exchange and store of value are very different products.

title: Are Monarchies Better for Economic Growth? Here's What the Empirical Evidence Says.
description: The evidence suggests that monarchies—especially small ones—are more peaceful, stable, and protective of private property than their republican neighbors.

title: The United States Has Declared Defeat in Two More Wars
description: Now that the average American voter is barely paying attention—and that the US is facing an economic crisis and weak recovery—it has become politically expedient to move further toward wrapping up a couple more lost wars.

title: Not Even Gretchen Whitmer Wants More of the CDC's Lockdowns
description: The political climate that fostered panic and lockdowns a year ago is now changing. Legislatures are turning against governors and the public is no longer hysterical with fear. Politicians aren't sure what to do.

title: 12 Myths Fueling Government Overreach in Times of Crisis
description: We must act now! It's better to do something than nothing! This has never happened before! The experts will show us the way! From the great depression to the crises of today, we hear these claims over and over again.

title: The State-Corporate Convergence in Our State of Emergency
description: The current political trend is toward corporate-state monopolization over all aspects of life, with increasing control by approved "private" principals over information and opinion, economic production, and the political sphere.

title: You Won't Learn Much about Fascism in this Book on "Fascism"
description: Jason Stanley's book on fascism is a jumbled mess which seems primarily to exist for the purpose of smearing everything Stanley doesn't like with the label of "fascism."

title: Texas Ended Lockdowns and Mask Mandates. Now Locked-Down States Are Where Covid Is Growing Most
description: Don’t expect Fauci and his supporters to give up on insisting that New York and Michigan are doing "the right thing" while Texas and Florida are embracing "human sacrifice" as a part of a "death cult."

title: A Jobless Recovery Is Coming to Europe
description: The destruction of the free market, competition, and innovation may seem appealing to some now, but the likely outcome of poor employment, negative real wage growth, and stagnation should be a real cause of concern.

title: Polarization in Washington Is Forcing Politicians to Decentralize
description: From gun control to abortion, gridlock and polarization in Washington forces policymakers to look to state and local governments as the centers of political reform.

title: Biden's Big Spending Plans Will Not Revive the Economy
description: Even without deficits or new taxes, Biden's infrastructure spending plan will only create more malinvestment and inflict further damage on an already weakened economy.

description: In the 1960s, politicians and bureaucrats had nearly unbounded faith in the ability to plan a nearly perfect society. Things didn't turn out as they had planned.

title: Economic Collapse Has Turned Many Europeans against the EU
description: Ironically, the economic collapse in Europe has united both the poor and rich members of the EU in agreement that the EU has none of their best interests at heart. The political winds have shifted and are blowing against the EU.

title: The Importance of Economic Theory in Understanding Historical Data
description: "History cannot teach us any general rule, principle, or law. There is no means to abstract from a historical experience a posteriori any theories or theorems concerning human conduct and policies."

title: The Incorporation Doctrine Broke the Constitutional System
description: It's a mistake to think freedom is protected by having the Supreme Court declare what is "constitutional," thus imposing centralized federal law on all the states.

title: Central Bankers Gone Wild: It's a New Era at the Fed
description: When people are scared they let the authorities get away with all sorts of nonsense. We're seeing this with the Federal Reserve right now.

title: Free the Liquor Stores!
description: Free the liquor stores to sell what products they want, what days of the week they want, what hours they want, and to whom they want.

title: Governments Have Crippled the World's Economies. Revolution May Soon Follow.
description: Mises knew: “Mass unemployment destroys the moral foundations of the social order. The young people…forced to remain idle, are the ferment out of which the most radical political movements are formed."

title: Why GDP Metrics Won't Tell Us Much about the Post-COVID Recovery
description: GDP can be increased through both government spending and printing new money. So, naturally, once lockdowns end we'll see a big rebound in GDP. But that doesn't tell us if the private sector is actually better off.

title: Three Ways Law Enforcement Must Be Reformed Right Now
description: End immunity. End police unions. End the drug war.

title: Riots: Not Fun nor Profit for the Rest of Us
description: Riots are not the answer to police abuse. The answer lies in making drastic reforms to how police agencies function, up to and including privatization. Contrary to the popular narrative, it's not just nonwhites who are in danger. We're all targets of the state's enforcers.

title: Why It's Rational to Fear Cops
description: Not all (or even most) police are needlessly violent. But it is rational to conclude, upon seeing a person in a police uniform, that this person can—if he wishes to—abuse his power with near impunity.

title: The Jones Act: 100 Years of Failed Protectionism
description: June 5 marks the one hundredth anniversary of the Jones Act, a law passed to protect the domestic water transportation industry from outside competition.

title: The Media Has Conveniently Forgotten George W. Bush's Many Atrocities
description: George W. Bush has resurfaced to pander to the Left and the media in hopes of getting some attention. Apparently, Bush's brutal history of lies, wars, and torture is all fine now since he said some nice things condemning racism.

title: Entrepreneurship in the Time of COVID-19
description: It is always a challenge for entrepreneurs to try and predict what customers will want in the future. But now things are even more unpredictable. And government regulations aren't helping either.

title: Mr. Trump, Don't Deploy the Military to American Cities without Their Consent
description: Some conservatives insist on calling for the president to deploy troops to pacify rioters even without the consent of state governments in affected areas. If this happens, it will be yet another nail in the coffin of the principles of decentralization, subsidiarity, and limited federal power.

title: Richard Cobden: Exemplar of Liberty, Property, and Peace
description: Richard Cobden today is an underappreciated hero of peace and freedom in trade, and he fought the power of the state at every turn.

title: Three Ways Lockdowns Paved the Way for These Riots
description: COVID lockdowns (1) threw millions out of work, (2) increased police harassment of peaceful people, (3) cut people off from key institutions that reduce social conflict. This made a volatile situation far worse.

title: War for Hong Kong?
description: The United States has been trying to provoke China into a conflict for years. But Americans benefit far more from peace with China. We shouldn't fall for the state's latest hate campaign against foreigners.

title: New York: The Corona Crisis Shows the Benefits of Localism Yet Again
description: COVID-19 is not really a "national" issue. It has affected different areas in very different ways.

title: Five Ways to Improve Social Media (and the Internet)
description: Social media platforms are indeed private firms and can publish or edit whatever they like—subject of course to the terms of service between the platform and users who generate content.

title: Why Abusive Cops So Often Keep Their Jobs
description: When you hear a cop has been fired from his job for some heinous act, be sure to check back a few months later. He may have been rehired thanks to the fact that it's very easy for cops to appeal termination and win.

title: Why Socialists Love the Phrase "It's Not Real Socialism"
description: A big reason that socialist ideology has staying power is the tactic of blaming the many failures and disasters of socialist regimes on the alleged fact the regimes "aren't real socialism."

title: Michael Flynn, Lori Loughlin, and the Permanent Culture of Prosecutorial Abuse
description: It’s important to call the government and media on this unholy alliance, whether you view their targets as sympathetic or not. If we stay silent when they come for our enemies, they will ultimately come for us.

title: There's No End in Sight to the Zombie Economy
description: Put simply, if it were not for accommodative monetary policy, these firms would have otherwise shut down by now. Once again, the Fed is refusing to allow the invisible hand to rein in the excess for fear of a liquidity crisis, credit crunch, and worse.

title: Defining "Inflation" Correctly
description: The real problem with inflation, properly understood is that it is essentially a wealth transfer away from the most productive parts of the economy. This causes bubbles and economic fragility.

title: Two Analogies for the Economy That the Media Keeps Getting Wrong
description: Ultimately, we need not rely on the government (i.e., the “king’s men” putting Humpty-Dumpty back together again). People acting freely in a marketplace could do it all by themselves. If only the government would let them.

title: An L-Shaped Recovery Is Not an Anomaly, It Is the Norm.
description: The massive bailout of indebted sectors that already had overcapacity and were in process of obsolescence may also drive the largest wave of malinvestment in decades. If the previous recoveries came with poor wage and capital expenditure growth and high debt, the next one will likely be even worse.

title: Minneapolis Riots Are a Reminder That Police Don't Protect You or Your Property
description: Police are not legally obligated to provide protection from criminals. Nor are they motivated to go after hardened criminals or investigate violent crime. Self defense (or private security) is the only reliable option.

title: Nozick Once Again
description: If time preference is genetically built into humans, are they double discounting future goods? Does this mean people should stop trying to weigh time in their calculations?

title: 3 Reasons States Will Reopen Regardless of What Trump Says
description: The reality of mandatory shutdowns is that state and local governments are now in the driver's seat, and that means that state and local politics is what really matters.

title: The German Court's Unexpected Blow to the ECB
description: A high German court recently ruled that the European Central Bank has overstepped the bounds of its power. The angry response from high-ranking European bureaucrats tells us a lot about what they want for the EU.

title: Three Ways Lockdowns Are Costing Human Lives
description: If we do not correctly take into account the opportunity cost, in terms of lives that can be lost from lockdowns, then we will most likely continue to make bad decisions in the future.

title: Politicians' COVID Mania Ravages Maryland
description: James Bovard reports form Maryland, where the COVID-19 lockdowns have decimated employment and the rules only apply to powerless ordinary people. Cops and politicians can do as they like.

title: The Hydroxychloroquine Controversy Is a Reminder That Prescription Laws Are a Government Racket
description: In a free country, doctors would be free to prescribe whatever drugs they wish to anyone for any reason. In fact, individuals should be free to buy drugs without a special government-required doctor's note.

title: Coronavirus Propaganda Mimics War Propaganda
description: Propaganda kills, but it also works. Many of the same tactics employed to destroy opposition to the Iraq War are being used today against opponents of lockdowns.

title: COVID Ethics: It's Immoral to Confine Innocent People Who Might Be a Threat
description: The possibility that someone might pose a threat to another at a future time is not sufficient reason to revoke a person's property rights.

title: What the Failed 55-MPH Speed Limit Law Tells Us about COVID Lockdowns
description: Americans were once harangued by government "experts" about the need to slow down on highways in order to save lives. Few listened. Today, laws demanding everyone "stay at home" may suffer a similar fate.

title: Why Congressional "Oversight" of the Bureaucracy Is No Such Thing
description: Neither voters nor politicians watch the bureaucracy very carefully, so they respond as one might expect—advancing their own and their favorites' interests, at the expense of the public they are supposedly working for.

title: How We Might Respond to a Pandemic Were Society Not So Dominated by the State
description: The state currently enjoys a vastly unbalanced share of the power within a society, such an arrangement is not in any way preordained, and the assumption that it must be betrays a narrowness of vision and a lack of historical knowledge.

title: The Fed Is Doing "Whatever It Takes" to Prop Up the Economy. That's a Very Bad Thing.
description: There's now no difference between monetary policy and other government programs designed to prop up firms, industries, and other favored groups. The Fed is simply another government planning agency.

title: The Big Reason Mises Rejected Marx's Dialectical Materialism
description: The weird thing about dialectical materialism is that Marx seems to have cobbled it together from two philosophies that contradicted each other.

title: To Prevent Problematic Inflation, We Need More Production. Which Means There's Trouble Ahead.
description: Price inflation is so difficult to predict, because there are so many moving parts: money supply, demand, money velocity, and supply of goods and services.

title: The Folly of "Ask What You Can Do for Your Country"
description: Governments often demand that you "ask what you can do for your country," but those governments never guarantee us anything in return for our sacrifice.

title: It Seems That Everyone Who Isn't a Hard-Core Leftist Is a "Libertarian"
description: It seems that if you're mildly against the drug war and sky-high taxes, you're a "libertarian" to many left-wing commentators—even if you also support programs like "universal basic income" and renewable energy boondoggles.

title: Central Banks Are Destroying What Was Left of Free Markets
description: The Fed and other central banks are entering into a huge money-printing experiment in hopes of keeping the government-spending machine going at full speed forever. The unintended consequences will be highly destructive.

title: Why Official Inflation Measures Don't Work
description: In theory, it is possible to adjust inflation measures to account for the many constant changes in prices resulting from changing demand, quality, and innovations. But it's essentially impossible to execute these adjustments accurately.

title: Three Ways the Coronavirus May Significantly Accelerate Political Decentralization
description: Although national tragedies tend to bring a country together, it seems clear that the coronavirus will leave America as divided as it has been in modern history.

title: Why Those COVID-19 Models Aren't Real Science
description: Lord Kelvin once said, “If you cannot measure it, then it is not science” and “your theory is apt to be based more upon imagination than upon knowledge.” This would certainly seem to apply to the many COVID-19 models now used to destroy human rights across the globe.

title: Nozick on Time Preference
description: Can indifference be demonstrated in action?

title: A Global Race to the Bottom: How Central Banks Are Responding to the COVID Crisis
description: Now, more than ever, we're in uncharted waters when it comes to central banks and monetary policy. Economist Brendan Brown takes a look at where we are and what the future might hold for central banks' race to the bottom.

title: How Government Intervention Triggers Depressions
description: Thanks to past interventions, the economy is now rife with malinvestments and prices that don't reflect real demand. The solution is to allow deflation and other types of painful readjustment. Otherwise true growth will elude us.

title: Why Didn't the 1958 and 1918 Pandemics Destroy the Economy? Hint: It's the Lockdowns
description: The 1958 pandemic killed twice as many people as COVID-19 has so far. Yet, the economy in 2020 has collapsed far worse than either in 1958 or the far worse pandemic of 1918.

title: Why an Economy Can't Work without Market Prices
description: Prices determined in the marketplace are absolutely essential to a functioning economic system.  This is no less true if today's property was redistributed unjustly in the past. Market prices today are the path to recovery.

title: We’re All in This Together. But Not in the Way You Think.
description: Some claim "the rich" will be fine—or even better off—after the COVID panic destroys the economy for most of us. But there's a problem: the wealthy depend heavily on an economy fueled by the production and consumption of all workers and entrepreneurs.

title: Do Lockdowns Work? Mounting Evidence Says No
description: Most of the world's regimes enthusiastically destroyed their economies and consigned millions to destitution (and a rising tide of resulting health problems) in pursuit of a trendy and unproven theory. There's still not evidence that the lockdowns worked.

title: The Japanese Love of Keynesian Economics Might Finally Be Coming to an End
description: Decades of Keynesian policy have crippled the Japanese economy. Only a turn toward free markets offer a real way out.

title: Do Lockdowns Work? Mounting Evidence Says No
description: Most of the world's regimes enthusiastically destroyed their economies and consigned millions to destitution (and a rising tide of resulting health problems) in pursuit of a trendy and unproven theory. There's still not evidence that the lockdowns worked.

title: The Japanese Love of Keynesian Economics Might Finally Be Coming to an End
description: Decades of Keynesian policy have crippled the Japanese economy. Only a turn toward free markets offer a real way out.

title: Hacksawing the Economy: How Lockdowns Are in the Tradition of Civil War Surgeons
description: Hacking off soldiers' limbs was a favorite technique of Civil War surgeons, largely because doctors wanted to avoid blame for later cases of gangrene. So doctors erred on the "safe" side. Many patients may have disagreed.

title: Krugman: We Need More Unemployment—to Save Us from Unemployment
description: Paul Krugman is now claiming that reopening the economy and allowing people to go to work almost surely will cause a depression.

title: How Modern Economics Has Lost Its Way: It's All About the "Unseen"
description: The difference between modern economics and proper economic thinking lies in taking the step that comes after arriving at the "unseen," to the "unrealized."

title: How Words Like "Essential" and "Need" Are Abused by Politicians
description: We live in an age when politicians decide what is "essential" and what isn't. It's a grave abuse of power and common sense.

title: Money Supply Growth in April Ballooned to a New High
description: Fueled by unprecedented quantitative easing, central bank asset purchases, and various stimulus packages, the money supply growth rate ballooned in April to an all-time high.

title: The ECB Has Been Hiding Risk. They Won't Be Able to Do It Much Longer.
description: The ECB can disguise the risk for a while, but the reality of the mounting debt and tax burden ahead is probably going to end in a debt crisis.

title: Thanks to Shutdowns, Many Will Learn That Public Schooling Isn't All That Essential After All
description: Panic over the COVID-19 virus has led to the closure of many schools and new forays into education outside the government school system. Many will find that they don't need the state's schools at all.

title: State Lockdowns Are Creating a Mental Health Disaster
description: With their bizarre and extreme lockdowns, governments are forcing very low-risk populations to endure social isolation and unemployment. The mental health effects will be significant.

title: The Problem with Measuring "Happiness"
description: Money really does buy happiness—up to a point. But at all income levels, happiness is very, very subjective.

title: The Federal Deficit Is Setting New Records as Spending Explodes
description: US government debt is spiraling upward, with debt-to-GDP rising to World War II levels. How long can this last?

title: State Lockdowns Are Creating a Mental Health Disaster
description: With their bizarre and extreme lockdowns, governments are forcing very low-risk populations to endure social isolation and unemployment. The mental health effects will be significant.

title: Adam Smith and Benevolence
description: Buyers and sellers in the free market do indeed act from self-interest, but Adam Smith never argued that this excludes friendly feelings for those they do business with.

title: Ludwig von Mises’s "Circulation Credit" Theory of the Trade Cycle
description: The latest installment in the Understanding Money Mechanics series summarizes the theory of the business cycle originally published in 1912 by Ludwig von Mises and elaborated by Friedrich Hayek.

title: Why Media Coverage of COVID-19 Has Been So Bad
description: Media outlets, both left and right, are mostly narrative driven. Also, journalists have a tendency to lazily reprint whatever "experts" say. This makes media reporting thoroughly unreliable.

title: The Clenched COVID Fist of Government
description: Governments create nothing, and only excel at coercion and violence. This is why governments are enthusiastic about shutting down economies but seem unsure about how to open them.

title: The School Closures Are a Big Threat to the Power of Public Schools
description: For many parents, the ongoing closure of public schools will just reinforce growing suspicions that public schools just aren't worth it anymore. Maybe they never were.

title: Germany Pushes Back against the ECB's Bailouts
description: The EU has now become essentially a makeshift, lawless regime designed to prop up bankrupt states. So much so, in fact, that even the German supreme court has become alarmed.

title: More Protectionism and Regulation Won't Fix the Economy
description: Trade controls and immigration quotas are just more government regulation. And that won't help revive the economy.

title: Germany Pushes Back against the ECB's Bailouts
description: The EU has now become essentially a makeshift, lawless regime designed to prop up bankrupt states. So much so, in fact, that even the German supreme court has become alarmed.

title: More Protectionism and Regulation Won't Fix the Economy
description: Trade controls and immigration quotas are just more government regulation. And that won't help revive the economy.

title: Viruses versus Lockdowns: It's Not about Tradeoffs
description: Presenting "saving lives" as a more or less equal alternative to commerce and community is a misguided view of what the lockdown debate is really all about.

title: Can Monopoly Money Save the Stock Market? Or Will It Buy Stagnation?
description: Rather than spurring real economic gains, the Federal Reserve’s unorthodox QE program has supported and extended the debt grid and generated asset exuberance. But this can only go on as long as there's capacity for more debt.

title: Negative Interest Rates: Rewarding Profligacy
description: Why would an investor buy a bond that pays a negative interest rate? The answer lies in understanding how central banks manipulate the economy.

title: How the COVID-19 Lockdowns Will Increase Resentment of the Elderly
description: How do the shutdowns increase ageism? Because millions have arguably been thrown out of work in the name of protecting the elderly. The resulting economic devastation comes at the expense of younger workers, parents, students, and families.

title: Why Has There Been So Little Consumer Price Inflation?
description: Prices of consumer goods have grown rather slowly in spite of sizable money supply growth. Why is there a gap?

title: Three Reasons Why the Eurozone Recovery Will Be Poor
description: The eurozone needs to understand that if it decides to increase taxes to address the rising debt due to the COVID-19 response, its ability to recover will be irreparably damaged.

title: Why Does Brazil’s Bolsonaro Refuse To Lock Down His Country's Economy?
description: While the Left has agitated for more government spying and harsher "lockdowns," Brazil's president—perhaps fearing economic implosion—has been reluctant to crack down.

title: How This Crisis Differs from the 2008–2009 Financial Crisis
description: In this crisis the money supply has already increased far more than during the last crisis. But it's hard to say when this will produce inflation because we're still in the midst of a demand shock and a collapse in oil prices.

title: Money Velocity and Prices
description: Prices and purchasing power are determined by how individual consumers value goods and services. The "velocity of money" won't help us understand prices or the money supply.

title: This Giant Monopolist Needs to Declare Bankruptcy and Reorganize
description: If organizations like the Federal Reserve and governments were forced to compete in a real economy, they would have been forced to declare bankruptcy, reorganize, and split up into smaller pieces long ago.

title: Europe's Communists Are Trying to Blame COVID-19 on Markets and "Neoliberalism"
description: Far from being a sign of alleged capitalist brutality, the spread of international trade and market freedom is a sign of greater global cooperation and solidarity.

title: Robert Nozick on Austrian Economics
description: It isn’t a good argument against Austrian economics that someone might come up with a science that made better predictions. You have to show us the science, so that it can be compared with praxeology. Suffice it to say that this hasn’t been done.

title: Governments Are the Real Price Gougers
description: Although politicians lecture private companies for raising prices, it is governments that have for decades raised the prices of goods and services by limiting supply and raising costs.

title: The COVID Stimulus is the Government’s Latest Rejection of Say’s Law
description: No matter what levers are pulled by the fiscal and monetary authorities, stones will not be turned into bread.

title: How Many Lives Will Politicians Sacrifice in the Name of Fighting COVID-19?
description: In a world of scarcity, there are no solutions, only tradeoffs.

title: How Government Spending Can Make the Debt Burden Look Smaller than It Really Is
description: Governments can increase GDP numbers simply by spending more, and this can reduce debt as a percentage of GDP. But what if we calculate GDP using only private spending?

title: When Governments Switched Their Story from "Flatten the Curve" to "Lockdown until Vaccine"
description: At some point in early April, the official narrative switched form "don't let hospitals get overwhelmed" to "you're locked down for years until there's a vaccine."

title: Some Insightful Entrepreneurs Planned for a Pandemic
description: Although many claim "nobody saw this coming," some entrepreneurs planned ahead and also have found ways to cater to customers under new conditions.

title: Be Thankful for Those Who "Only Do It for the Money"
description: Doing things for money does not justify moral condemnation, unless using money to support your family, live up to the agreements you have made, and to try not to burden others justifies moral condemnation.

title: How All That Extra Stimulus Money Could Lead to Price Inflation
description: More money creation doesn't necessarily mean higher consumer prices. But, if production is falling while consumers use their stimulus checks to buy food and clothing, we could see noticeable price inflation.

title: Police Are Complicit in Politicians' Disregard for the Rule of Law
description: Police have long shown a preference for enforcing petty laws against petty offenders. After all, real violent criminals fight back. The current COVID-19-induced crackdown on business owners has made things even worse.

title: The Global Airline Industry Is in Even Worse Shape Than You Think
description: The current crisis for airlines is even worse than it was after 9/11.

title: How Governments Broke the Oil Market
description: The oil industry became one of the main areas of malinvestment in the years of massive liquidity and low yields. This perpetuated excess capacity and kept inefficient companies unnecessarily alive.

title: Facing Economic Disaster, France Turns against Globalism
description: France faces a future of spiraling debt and declining economic growth. So Emmanuel Macron has now embraced economic nationalism as a way out. It's not likely to work.

title: Money Creation—Not Low Interest Rates—Is Behind the Boom-Bust Cycle
description: When it comes to understanding business cycles, Austrian school scholars stand on firm ground while critic John Tamny is all at sea.

title: As Oil Craters, Mexico's Government Still Bets on Its Oil Monopoly
description: With oil prices in likely long-term tailspin, corrupt governments can't count on oil sales to bail them out anymore. But Mexico's government didn't get the memo and still clings to the state oil monopoly.

title: In Defense of Landlords
description: Landlords invest their stored labor—savings—at a risk and with the knowledge that they won't recoup it for some time. In creating or renovating rental properties, they aid those who can't store their labor yet—tenants and laborers.

title: The Marshall Plan Myth Lives On
description: Those who really want to help people in poor countries should turn to free trade, not to yet another welfare program.

title: Austrian School Scholars Are Right to Be Worried about This Economy
description: Austrian economists do not have crystal balls, but Austrian business cycle theory provides a sure foundation for identifying looming economic crises and exacerbating factors, even if the precise timing of a downturn cannot be known.

title: Politicians Have Destroyed Markets and Ignored Human Rights with Alarming Enthusiasm
description: Politicians and media have combined with an obedient and frightened electorate to abolish civil liberties and destroy the markets that are so key to fighting poverty.

title: Money Pumping Won’t Fix What’s Wrong with the Economy
description: The current bust has been made worse by previous periods of easy money, which destroyed the wealth creation that is critical to sustaining a growing economy.

title: Next in Coronavirus Tyranny: Forced Vaccinations and "Digital Certificates"
description: Proponents of mandatory vaccines and enhanced surveillance are trying to blackmail the American people by arguing that the lockdown cannot end unless we create a healthcare surveillance state and make vaccination mandatory.

title: The Freedom of Individuals Still Matters—Even If COVID Warriors Say It Doesn't
description: Human beings do not exist to be pawns in a game of lockdowns and collective action.

title: Decades of Productivity Gains Have Made Our Debt Bomb Manageable (For Now)
description: Although the money supply has greatly increased, accompanying growth in production has made it possible to keep the current system of immense debt increase going for a long time.

title: To Avoid a Collapse of the Eurozone, Europe Moves Closer to a European Megastate
description: Debt-ridden countries such as Italy will come to rely more and more on Germans and other northern Europeans to finance their debt. This will require a more unified Europe. Or the whole thing may collapse.

title: Murray Rothbard and Thomas Kuhn
description: Thomas Kuhn influenced Rothbard by demolishing the notion that the history of science is one of continual progress. The truth is that once a paradigm becomes established, its basic tenets are not questioned at all until major problems crop up.

title: Keynesian Fallacies Are Not Just Wrong, but Dangerous
description: As the federal government embarks on racking up an estimated $3.7 trillion in extra debt this fiscal year alone, it’s critical for the public to understand just how destructive such action will be.

title: America Is a Technocracy, Not a Democracy
description: The people who really run the country are unelected "experts" and bureaucrats at the central banks, at public health agencies, spy agencies, and an expanding network of boards and commissions.

title: Deregulation Is the Path to Increasing the Supply of Medical Services
description: If we're serious about increasing the capacity of our medical institutions, free trade and deregulation offer real solutions.

title: Three Ways to Speed Recovery from the Economic Crisis
description: Chile, like many other countries, needs to do this: cut taxes, deregulate, and limit spending.

title: This Crisis Will Not Bring Americans Together and Maybe That Is a Good Thing
description: Thanks to the growth of the state over time, political stakes have become much higher, and groups fear that they will be crushed by the other side if they lose. Crisis-induced cohesion is not a silver bullet, but rather a ticking time bomb.

title: Testing Deregulation Can Help Fight COVID-19
description: The fight against COVID-19 would benefit from a comprehensive deregulation of the market for testing. A brief look at India shows the damaging roadblocks to solutions that regulations impose.

title: A Protest from France
description: The lockdowns of the past month have not been conducive to the common good. While they have saved the lives of many people, they have also endangered—and are still endangering—the lives and livelihoods of many others. They have created a new and dangerous political precedent.

title: Unemployment Kills: The Longer Lockdowns Last, the Worse It Will Get
description: Thirty million Americans are now unemployed, in part thanks to government "lockdowns." Meanwhile, unemployment in many cases doubles the unemployed person's risk of death through disease, suicide, or drug overdose.

title: The Unseen Costs of Government-Forced Lockdowns
description: With apologies to Frédéric Bastiat, this is how his great essay "The Seen and the Unseen" might read if applied to the current government-forced lockdowns forcing business owners into bankruptcy across America and the world.

title: Government Regulation against "Monopolies" Only Lowers Our Standard of Living
description: The whole idea of government regulating so-called monopolies in order to promote competition is based on fallacies. If anything, such intervention only stifles market competition and lowers living standards.

title: Bitcoin and the Theory of Money
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics,
description: In the latest installment of Understanding Money Mechanics, Robert Murphy explains what Bitcoin is, how it works, and how it fits into Misesian monetary theory.

title: COVID-19 Is Teaching Us Decentralization Is Needed More Now Than Ever
description: We need to move beyond the stale platitudes of trying to fix politics in DC. The chattering class’s lamentation about the divisiveness of politics is frankly silly. In some ways, polarization is our friend.

title: New York vs. Texas: NY Has Nearly 50 Times More COVID-19 Deaths Per Capita
description: New York and New Jersey have produced more COVID-19 deaths than the rest of the country combined. So politicians have repeatedly claimed that the nation is "two weeks behind New York" to drum up support for extreme lockdown measures.

title: What the COVID-19 Crisis Means for Europe and the Eurozone
description: It is fundamentally wrong to put the entire economy at the service of a single goal and to commit to a single solution. Human action always involves weighing up different goals and different means.

title: President's Impact Report — First Quarter 2020
description: See what we've accomplished in the first quarter of 2020.

title: The Current Crisis Has Its Roots in the Central Bank
description: By protecting banks from the costs of poor investment decisions, central banks encourage further risk taking and malinvestment. They also prevent liquidation, which brings failed businesses' assets to the market at bargain prices, allowing new businesses to emerge from the detritus.

title: The Fed Has Gone Nuts. And It Can Get Worse.
description: The new Fed policy proposals being floated carry significant political risk, because they enjoy support not just from the redistributionist left, but also “business conservatives” happy to raid our future to make their pain stop.

title: Ending the Lockdowns Isn't about Saving Money. It's about Saving Lives.
description: "Saving lives versus saving money" comparisons confuse ends with means. The end of saving the economy is not to have more money. The end is to have resources necessary to preserve the lives and health of countless human beings.

title: Freedom in Prices Ends Shortages. Even with Toilet Paper.
description: Whether we're talking about gasoline or toilet paper, the details of how the good is produced are irrelevant to the fact that price controls cause shortages. Only price freedom ends them.

title: The COVID-19 Crisis Is Driving the EU to the Brink
description: As the debt bombs in Italy and Spain and France get worse, it increasingly looks like the eurozone will have to bail out a huge portion of the European economy. Either that, or break up the EU, provoking a new crisis.

title: How Markets Price a Pandemic—and How They Lower Risk
description: Regardless of government actions, many consumers, workers, and producers may seek changes that reduce exposure to disease in the workplace. The best way to do this is through markets.

title: Why the Current Unemployment Is Worse Than the Great Depression
description: Even though the official unemployment rate is probably not quite as high as it was in 1933, there are reasons to believe that our labor market is currently in even worse  shape economically than it was at the lowest depths of the Great Depression.

title: How Shutdowns Will Keep Killing the Economy, Even When They're Over
description: Part of what made the Great Depression last so long was increased uncertainty about what regulation or tax the government might impose next. Today's looming threat of ongoing "shutdowns" creates a very similar situation.

title: Praxeology and Mathematical Logic
description: Some argue that praxeology's deductions should be formalized using mathematical logic, but such an approach would be inappropriate for human action, whose axioms are known.

title: This Bust Wasn't Caused by a Virus
description: The COVID-19 panic may have sped up the beginning of this economic crisis, but the virus wasn’t the cause. The real cause of the crisis was the boom that came before it.

title: Business Owners Understand Why the Economy Can't Just Be "Reopened"
description: Business owners and entrepreneurs are our "meal ticket," our "golden goose." The sort of thinking that shuts them down on the whims of politicians poses grave economic threats to us all.

title: The Destructive Effects of the Coronavirus Relief Package
description: Central banks are at the heart of government mega–bailout packages. Their ongoing expansion of the money supply won't end well.

title: Central Banks and the Next Crisis: From Deflation to Stagflation
description: When governments and central banks announce massive stimulus packages at the very beginning of a crisis, they bet on a speedy recovery and a return to normal as if nothing had happened. This is far from the case.

title: If Face Masks Are Mandatory, Then It’s Time to End Mask Patents
description: Governments are set to make mask wearing mandatory in many places. Yet some companies are committed to limiting supply and charging monopoly prices thanks to government-created patents.

title: Anthony Fauci: When Politics Trumps Science
description: When it comes to diseases, Anthony Fauci has a well established pattern of skipping the science phase, and going directly to press conferences and political posturing.

title: Your Supermarket Overlords: Why Barbados Needs a Voluntary Quarantine
description: The fact that people break curfew just proves that smaller, decentralized communities are better at organizing than a few top-down planners. Barbadian neighborhoods do a much better job of self-regulating.

title: Why Markets Are Rallying as Millions Become Unemployed
description: Wouldn’t you feel great knowing that your stock picking is fully insured by the Fed? Billionaires and wealthy hedge fund managers know the feeling.

title: Your Supermarket Overlords: Why Barbados Needs a Voluntary Quarantine
description: The fact that people break curfew just proves that smaller, decentralized communities are better at organizing than a few top-down planners. Barbadian neighborhoods do a much better job of self-regulating.

title: Three Reasons Why Politicians Must Leave Oil Markets Alone
description: Efforts by US policymakers to boost crude prices and to throw a lifeline to high-cost US crude producers is the exact opposite of what prices are telling us the market needs at this time.

title: Rothbard on Why We Need Entrepreneurs
description: Capitalists and entrepreneurs serve distinct functions in the real economy. Capitalists save money that then maintains production processes until final goods are produced. Entrepreneurs adjust the capital structure in light of uncertainty to produce the most desired goods. Capitalists are rewarded with interest, entrepreneurs with profit.

title: Exactly How Many Deaths Are Needed to Justify Giving Governments Control of Everything?
description: What is the number of deaths due to disease which justifies the total abandonment of the rule of law and basic human freedoms? Sixty thousand? One hundred thousand? Three hundred thousand? Supporters of the current police state ought to pin down a number for us at which all rights are forfeit.

title: The Experts Have No Idea How Many COVID-19 Cases There Are
description: Collecting government data on the total number of cases of COVID-19 has always been a mess. The number is likely far higher than the "official" numbers, and this means government proclamations about fatality rates are little more than bad guesses.

title: Money Supply Growth Surges to 92-Month High
description: During March 2020, year-over-year (YOY) growth in the money supply was at 11.37 percent. We're now seeing a trend similar to what we saw during late 2008 and early 2009.

title: We Can't Just "Restart" the Economy Where We Left Off
description: If we're serious about maximizing the resources needed to combat COVID-19, we need an economy that is deregulated and flexible.

title: Preface to Anatomy of the Crash
description: One of the important aims of the Anatomy of the Crash is to highlight the truly global nature of the monetary policy failings since 2008—not simply critiquing the actions of the Federal Reserve, but their colleagues at the European Central Bank, the Bank of Japan, and elsewhere.

title: Finally Kicking the GDP Habit
description: GDP is fine for counting things like washing machines. But it is quite useless for counting other basic indicators of the quality of life.

title: Anthony Fauci, the "Learned Ignoramus"
description: Experts such as Anthony Fauci are experts only in the narrow field of their expertise. They have almost no knowledge or expertise in other fields, including—apparently—the basics of how human societies function.

title: Mises versus Rand on the Origins of Nazism
description: Ludwig von Mises and Ayn Rand held very different views about the origins of Nazism, and in this article I am going to describe these differences. Both involve German philosophical ideas.

title: Governments Make Us More Vulnerable in a Pandemic
description: If you are shocked by the extent to which Canada’s various governments have shut down the economy with the onset of COVID-19, you should be more shocked by how much they shut it down before COVID-19.

title: The 1497 Cornish Tax Rebellion
description: As states in various areas of the Continent embarked on centralization and territorialization in the fourteenth century, communities very often took up arms against forms of taxation. The Cornish Rebellion of 1497 against national taxation is an example of this trend.

title: Gun Control: Americans Have Been Lucky during the COVID-19 Panic, but It's Still a Toss-Up
description: So far, when it comes to disarming the population, governments haven't been quite as terrible as one might have predicted during the COVID-19 panic.

title: In Bid to Extend Lockdowns, Leftist Governors Embrace "States' Rights"
description: In an effort to defy Donald Trump, Andrew Cuomo, NBC, and CBS have suddenly embraced what they have long hated: state sovereignty and the extensive decentralization mandated by the Tenth Amendment.

title: COVID-19 Is Forcing Governments to Admit Their Regulations Aren't Really Necessary
description: From medical practices to grocery shipments, governments are loosening restrictions in order to keep goods and services affordable. But if these restrictions are unnecessary now, why claim they are ever necessary?

title: Decentralization and Privatization Haven't Gone Far Enough in Coronavirus Testing
description: Federal regulation of medical tests and testing needs to be ended and left to the states. And then state authority must be broken up and decentralized even further.
