title: The US Labor Market Will Heal Faster Than the European One
description: The key to recovering jobs quickly and efficiently is the combination of a flexible labor market, an attractive investment framework, and solid policies to preserve the business fabric of the country.

title: How to Think about the Fed Now
description: The Fed is, in effect, a lawless economic government unto itself. It is the lender of first resort, a kind of reverse pawnshop that pays top dollar for rapidly declining assets.

title: How Government Makes a Pandemic More Deadly
description: From trade barriers to disastrous government regulations, government intervention has crippled society's ability to respond well to the spread of disease.

title: How to Think about the Fed Now
description: The Fed is, in effect, a lawless economic government unto itself. It is the lender of first resort, a kind of reverse pawnshop that pays top dollar for rapidly declining assets.

title: How Government Makes a Pandemic More Deadly
description: From trade barriers to disastrous government regulations, government intervention has crippled society's ability to respond well to the spread of disease.

title: Central Banks around the World Embrace Unprecedented "Quantitative Easing"
description: From New York to London to Brussels to Tokyo, central banks in the last two weeks have embraced a wide variety of extraordinary inflationary measures to prop up insolvent banks and governments.

title: Flattening the Curve or Flattening Bellies? Africa's COVID-19 Dilemma
description: Africa is in no position to bring a halt to economic activity. Urban poverty and huge debts present an apparent choice between rampant disease and mass impoverishment.

title: In an Age of Pandemics We Need More Freedom to Trade, Not Less
description: It is thanks to global trade that we now have access to many more resources for treatment and prevention of disease, including COVID-19.

title: Government Victims and Entreprenurial Failure: Two Types of Conoranvirus Bankruptcies
description: The coronavirus crisis has unleashed two types of bankruptcies that are very different, have different causes, and should require different solutions.

title: Why This Bubble Economy Keeps Going and Going
description: Current global bailouts may put off global busts for quite some time. But they will weaken output and employment gains. People's standard of living will stagnate or even fall, even in the short term. With this comes impoverishment and perhaps even social unrest.

title: The Fed's Balance Sheet Skyrockets as It Doubles Down on Inflating Asset Prices
description: The Fed's portfolio is now 35 percent larger from the time the Fed promised to "taper" back its portfolio and "normalize." It is increasingly clear that there will not be any normalization. Ever.

title: Builders in Denial
description: This year, as in 2006, the real estate industry is in denial about the state of the economy.

title: Danish State Plans to Pay the Salaries of Private Sector Workers
description: The Danish state believes that the nation can avoid economic collapse if the state pays private sector workers' salaries. This, it is thought, will allow private companies to avoid layoffs. But there's a downside.

title: Even If the Fed Keeps Pumping Money, We May Still See Deflation
description: It is tempting to assume both money supply inflation and price inflation will come soon as the central banks pump new money. But if banks aren't lending because the economy is in disarray, the money supply may actually shrink, and prices may even fall.

title: Calls for Central Planning in the COVID-19 Panic Are like the Calls for the "War Socialism" of Old
description: Ludwig von Mises explained how "war socialism" doesn't win wars. Similarly, "COVID-19 socialism" won't win the "war" on disease.

title: Government Overreach in the Age of COVID-19
description: To ensure that the United States moves past this pandemic, we must minimize government infringements of civil liberties and maximize the incentives of private businesses and individuals who want to assist in our efforts to combat this “invisible enemy.”

title: Keynes Called Himself a Socialist. He Was Right.
description: John Maynard Keynes's supporters still insist that he was a mild and benign liberal. In truth, Keynes supported the blood-soaked Soviet regime and called himself a socialist.

title: Did Native Peoples Live in Harmony with Nature? It's Complicated.
description: The popular notion that indigenous peoples residing in a precapitalist order are particularly skillful at managing the earth's resources is a myth.

title: A Puzzle about Mises and Conscription
description: Not only are conscripts enslaved, often under brutal conditions, they can be sent to die in battle. Mises opposed conscription, but there was an exception.

title: Why Central Planning by Medical Experts Will Lead to Disaster
description: Medical experts have tunnel vision when it comes to disease and public policy, and they greatly overestimate their own abilities to anticipate unintended costs and consequences.

title: While the West Panicked, Some Asian Regimes Took a Different Path
description: Even Now, Japan and Hong Kong are moving only very slowly toward economic "lockdowns." Korea and Taiwan employ different strategies altogether.

title: Entrepreneurship Is the Foundation of a Productive Society
description: To spread the benefits of goods and services, we must first spread the mindset needed to take on the task of producing goods and services. That is, the mindset of entrepreneurship.

title: Why Mexico Fears Shutting Down Its Economy to Combat COVID-19
description: Although bureaucrats with safe jobs and luxury homes like Anthony Fauci continue to insist mass unemployment is merely "inconvenient," job losses mean many Mexicans could be staring grinding poverty in the face.

title: Why Mexico Fears Shutting Down Its Economy to Combat COVID-19
description: Although bureaucrats with safe jobs and luxury homes like Anthony Fauci continue to insist mass unemployment is merely "inconvenient," job losses mean many Mexicans could be staring grinding poverty in the face.

title: Free Trade Brings More Foreign Investment into the US. That's a Good Thing.
description: Politicians and pundits have a blind spot when it comes to international economic transactions. They ignore a portion of trade! In particular, they ignore trade in claims on future income—that is, stocks and bonds.

title: The Real Cost of Anti-Price-Gouging Laws
description: If buyers aren't allowed to compete in terms of prices, they'll be forced to compete in terms of time waiting, distance traveled, or other real costs.

title: Beyond the NAP: Rothbard's Full Case for Liberty
description: The nonaggression principle—"anything peaceful"—comes as close to a value-free analysis in a political, ethical, economic, and legal theory as conceivably possible. It was insufficient for Rothbard, because he rightly found it insufficient for liberty.

title: How Risk-Based Healthcare Could Make Us Healthier
description: A healthcare system based on responsible risk management systems would provide market incentives for people to improve health while cutting costs for some needy populations.

title: Education and the Coronavirus: Trying to Look on the Bright Side
description: Entrepreneurs can offer new ways of serving established markets, but large institutions will keep with what has worked in the past so long as it just continues to work in the present. Radical change happens only in an emergency. For the British university that time has now arrived.

title: The COVID-19 "Lockdowns" Are What Twenty-First-Century Mob Rule Looks Like
description: There is a misconception among critics of the COVID-19 lockdowns that they're being imposed over the howls of the local population, which wants freedom. If only that were true.

title: Airline Bailouts Destabilize the Economy and Inflate Asset Prices
description: The airline industry has clearly been prone to booms and busts for decades. Yet instead of planning for hard times, these corporate welfare machines called "airlines" use resources to inflate stock value and pad executive salaries.

title: Yes, There Are Tradeoffs between Disease Prevention and Economic Destruction
description: Noneconomists struggle to realize that scarcity results in the necessity of tradeoffs. During the COVID-19 pandemic, this difference in thinking causes them to wrongly accuse economists of "prioritizing money over lives."

title: Italy's Healthcare Sector Badly Needs Deregulation and More Private Spending
description: Thanks to regulations and a lack of private spending, Italy's healthcare system had very limited capacity even before the current crisis.

title: Freedom Still Matters, Even in the Midst of a Virus
description: “Whenever a single definite object is made the supreme end of the State…the State becomes for the time inevitably absolute.” We cannot allow combating a virus to overwhelm all other values in society.

title: Life and Health Are at Stake as the Economy Grinds to a Halt
description: The quality of the models being used by politicians to set COVID-19 policy is only as good as the data collected. Unfortunately, the data is not very good. Meanwhile, real costs arise from the ruined economy.

title: In March, US Deaths from COVID-19 Totaled Less Than 2 Percent of All Deaths
description: How much must total mortality increase to justify a global suspension of commerce and the rule of law? One percent? Ten percent? And what if overall mortality doesn't even go up?

title: How the Left Is Trying to Blame Capitalism for COVID-19 Deaths
description: The Left conveniently ignores dozens of state-dominated and state-controlled medical systems and decides that the lack of preparedness for COVID-19 was all the fault of those small slivers of healthcare systems that are actually private.

title: What "Lender of Last Resort" Is Supposed to Mean
description: Modern central banks have already moved far beyond what was once considered the proper role for a central bank as a "lender of last resort." Now Keynesians and MMTers want to take things even further.

title: Creating More Money Won't Revive the Economy
description: What the economy needs now is more real savings and more real production. Creating more money will not help with either of these things.

title: Égalité, Fraternité, Captivité
description: What we can learn from the Patriot Act is that during a time of crisis governments can pass legislation that impacts citizens’ lives long after the crisis of the day has passed.

title: All Crises Are Local
description: The coronavirus demonstrates how crises become local.

title: The Pandemic Exposed the Frailty of the Financial System
description: Contrary to Fed assumptions, we are not presently facing a problem of liquidity vis-à-vis Great Recession; we are confronted, instead, with a serious shortage of quality collateral.

title: Keynes and the Euthanasia of the Rentier
description: Over eighty years ago, Keynes condemned the rentier and welcomed his future disappearance. Following in his footsteps, politicians and central bankers today are ever closer to effectively bringing this about.

title: Japan Has Avoided a COVID-19 Panic. But the Global Recession Will Hit Hard
description: Whatever happens with the virus, the real story, the real historical change, is probably economic. Abenomics—Japan's ultra-Keynesian experiment—seems to be dead.

title: What Is the Good Entrepreneur to Do?
description: Some anticapitalists have tried to claim "good" entrepreneurs don't make profit the primary goal. Yet, without profit, an entrepreneur cannot serve the people who depend on him or her for goods and services.

title: The Pandemic Exposed the Frailty of the Financial System
description: Contrary to Fed assumptions, we are not presently facing a problem of liquidity vis-à-vis Great Recession; we are confronted, instead, with a serious shortage of quality collateral.

title: Capital Accumulation: The Way to Increase Wages
description: Real higher wages can't be created with a government fiat. Worker productivity must first be increased through greater investment.

title: The Fed Is Running Out of Bubbles to Create
description: With each passing recession, the Fed finds it harder to refuel the last bubble, but the market moves on to the new bubble as the Fed keeps interest rates artificially low.

title: Japan’s Productivity Has Been Slashed By Government Meddling, Not Demographics
description: The popular narrative is that demographics are driving Japan's declining worker productivity. But the real culprit is government regulations and a lack of entrepreneurship.

title: Equality and Levelling Down
description: Egalitarians think that equality has intrinsic value: they advocate it for its own sake, not just to forestall bad consequences. But why is a situation in which some in it have been made better off, and none worse off, worse than one of equality?

title: Bureaucrats Can't Fix This
description: Bureaucrats cannot conjure wealth from nothing. They only have what they extract from the private sector. Unfortunately, the bureaucrats are now starving the private sector of funding while making government budgets ever larger.

title: Do the Textbooks Get Money and Banking Backwards?
description: Over the years a chorus of critics has alleged that the textbook view of how a central banks buys government debt in "open market operations" is backwards. They argue that in reality commercial banks take the lead in making loans without regard to their reserves.

title: Price Controls Mean Shortages, Even during Pandemics
description: Despite many attempts at doing so, governments have never been able to conjure up more goods and services through price controls and other regulations.

title: How Easy Money Is Increasing the Devastation of the COVID-19 Panic
description: Central banks have created a brittle economy without real savings and without much room to maneuver. Central banks now want more of the same in a bid to fix what they broke.

title: The Crisis Has Exposed the Damage Done by Government Regulations
description: The shortages and lack of flexibility caused by government red tape during the COVID-19 crisis has forced many governments to rethink their many arbitrary and unnecessary regulations.

title: In a Crisis, the Most Innovative Entrepreneurs Make the Most Money. That's a Good Thing.
description: It is precisely during a crisis that private property, the price mechanism, and the profit and loss system are most important, and when the government can do the most damage.

title: It's Time to Track the FDA's Death Toll
description: Many Americans could die in the coming weeks and months thanks to the FDA’s blockade on coronavirus testing. Should we consider those victims as martyrs for the principle of bureaucratic supremacy?

title: The Problem with the "Renters' Rights" Movement
description: Both renters and landlords have plenty of troubles when it comes to working together. But putting government regulators in the mix won't help matters.

title: Want Political Change? Get Rid of Campaign Finance Regulations.
description: Campaign finance laws favor incumbents and the rich and famous. Real change requires more freedom and decentralization in how campaigns are funded.

title: The Federal Government Owns 92 Percent of Student Loans. Why Do Politicians Lie About It?
description: The federal government must accompany any loan forgiveness with a repeal of all programs for subsidizing and guaranteeing loans. Anything less would be a formula for socializing higher education.

title: Even Partial Liberalization Can Save a Nation from Poverty
description: Without markets, it would have been impossible for a country like Rwanda, ravaged by the war, to achieve the growth it has experienced over the past twenty years.

title: Why the World Has a Dollar Shortage, Despite Massive Fed Action
description: Can the US dollar lose its global reserve position? Sure it can, but not to a country that decides to commit the same monetary follies as the Fed. Most countries are trying to out-inflate the Fed. And that's good for the Fed.

title: How the Fed Sows Social Division and Mistrust
description: As the central bank continues to pick winners and losers with its profligate monetary policy, social divisions will worsen.

title: The Feds Are Suing Oracle for Discrimination, Even Though No One Has Complained
description: Federal agencies have destroyed the separation of powers that is supposed to exist in the US legal system, so agency bureaucrats now act as investigators, prosecutors, judges, and juries.

title: Even Partial Liberalization Can Save a Nation from Poverty
description: Without markets, it would have been impossible for a country like Rwanda, ravaged by the war, to achieve the growth it has experienced over the past twenty years.

title: This Is Not a Recession—This Is a Government-Imposed Shutdown of the Private Sector
description: We are about to enter a production slowdown—a collapse, really—not because some businesses miscalculated their investments, but because government intervened drastically and without warning to shut down all businesses.

title: The Political Management of the Coronavirus Crisis
description: The less agile and adaptive a society is, the more severe its impotence in a crisis. Thanks to an obsessive reliance on monetary policy to fix every problem, our society has increasingly abandoned innovation and productivity.

title: What If the Fed Did Nothing?
description: As with current Fed policy, there would be both winners and losers if the Fed did nothing. Either way, there will be pain, but without the Fed we'd actually build the foundation for a more sound and lasting economic system.

title: What Would Rothbard Say about the COVID-19 Panic?
description: No matter what the situation, no one has the right to compel someone to act for another's benefit, and that includes forced quarantines, business closures, and expropriations of medical equipment in the name of "public health."

title: How Governments (and the Fed) Make Life Harder for Young Families
description: Government institutions, including central banks, have long been responsible for increases in the cost of living. But the burden often falls most on those who are just starting out in their adult lives.

title: Canada Has Abolished Civil Liberties in the Name of "Safety"
description: The various levels of government in Canada have responded to the coronavirus pandemic. Their ill-advised solutions are to inflict economic hardship and withdraw civil liberties. The longer these authoritarian policies persist, the greater the risk to the social fabric.

title: "Cost Cutting" Is Necessary to Expand Real Investment
description: Many economists today think it's a bad thing when companies cut costs to increase profits. But this is a good thing that limits wasteful spending while setting the stage for more investment elsewhere.

title: The New Euro Stimulus Won't Save the Greek Economy
description: The Greeks haven't saved or produced enough to justify their high standard of living compared to other countries of the world. This is a fragile bubble economy made possible by European central bankers.

title: The Last Thing We Need Right Now Is Bernie's Proposed Tax on Financial Transactions
description: Bernie Sanders wants a tax on financial transactions so that every trade brings a penalty. While this most directly affects big traders, regular people will not be immune to the effects.

title: The Benefits of a Free Society during Pandemics
description: The idea that a free and mostly privatized society would let pandemics rage unchecked is based on a crude caricature. The truth is that a free society offers flexibility and resilience that a centralized system lacks.

title: Governments Can't Fix This Economic Crisis They Caused
description: The US and the world will rise from this crisis. What the government has to do is allow it. The government is there to facilitate, not to pick winners and losers.

title: Eminent Domain: Are Holdouts Really a Problem?
description: David Gordon is not convinced by the usual arguments claiming property owners ought to be forced to sell their property for an arbitrarily determined "market price."

title: COVID-19 and the Planners’ Need to Plan
description: Despite the fact that the CDC’s formal name includes the word “Prevention” and that its stated goals include various planning buzzwords, its managing of the COVID-19 response has been an unmitigated disaster.

title: The Noncrime Known as "Price Gouging"
description: Anti-price gouging laws mean that those who really end up getting the short end of the stick are those who don't have the time or the means to beat the crowds to the store. Worse off are those of lesser means who rely on public transportation or walking to transport groceries home.

title: Politicians Have Used This Crisis to Remind Us They're Mostly Wannabe Dictators
description: From small villages to Capitol Hill, politicians are using every opportunity to void the Bill of Rights and abolish all limits on their power.

title: Diversification versus Risk
description: The size of an entrepreneur's return on his investment is determined not by how much risk he assumes, but rather whether he complies with consumers' wishes.

title: Why Taiwan Hasn't Shut Down Its Economy
description: Taiwan's response to COVID-19 mostly means self-imposed quarantines and more transparency. It's basically the opposite of what Europe is doing.

title: The Use of Knowledge in Entrepreneurship
description: It is a marvel that imperfect, limited information available to the entrepreneur can be used to produce so much good for society.

title: More than Half of All US COVID-19 Deaths Occur in Only Four States
description: The effects of COVID-19 are not evenly distributed in the United States. Only certain regions are facing sizable strains on their resources. A nationwide lockdown would create huge economic costs for regions where the the costs of disease have been relatively low.

title: The Government's Pandemic Strategy Is a Reckless One
description: It's time to stop pretending that the policies favored by some biologists—who know nothing about how economies work to lessen the health effects of poverty—come without grave costs to public health.

title: Fear Makes It Easy for Governments to Expand Power
description: Why are governments so enthusiastic about shutting down businesses when other less draconian measures are available and prudent? The answer lies in the fact that governments can act with near impunity and want to maximize their power.

title: The Use of Knowledge in Entrepreneurship
description: It is a marvel that imperfect, limited information available to the entrepreneur can be used to produce so much good for society.

title: The State Has Seized Many New Powers. It Won't Let Go of Them Easily.
description: The state has used this virus scare to demand that politicians and bureaucrats be given near-total control over every aspect of life, including virtually every business and employer in America. Will this now be a permanent feature of American life?

title: The End of Civilization?
description: Even if the COVOID-19 virus turns out to be more severe than the skeptics give us reason to think it is, we can get through it. We cannot survive the end of the division of labor. It would be the finish of civilization as we know it.

title: The US's COVID-19 Death Rate Is Far below the Rates in Italy and Spain
description: Contrary to a recent headline, the US is not about to become the "epicenter" of COVID-19. In fact, the death rate of COVID-19 is lower in the US than at the same point in the timeline for many other countries we are told are comparable to the US.

title: With Bailouts, Governments Are the Big Winners
description: Every crisis caused by the unbacked paper money system expands the power of the states over economic and social life, and unfortunately, once the state has expanded its power, it is unlikely the trend will be reversed.

title: The Costs Are Mounting in this Government-Imposed Economic Collapse
description: The costs of this government-forced economic collapse—in terms of lost lives and ruined health—are likely to be devastating.

title: Diseases Are Bad. Government-Forced Shutdowns Are Often Worse.
description: There is a reason to panic. But the panic should be over how governments—who know so very little about the virus that they have decided warrants destroying the global economy—will create many new threats to health and well-being through their policies.

title: Diseases Are Bad. Government-Forced Shutdowns Are Often Worse.
description: There is a reason to panic. But the panic should be over how governments—who know so very little about the virus that they have decided warrants destroying the global economy—will create many new threats to health and well-being through their policies.

title: We're Learning Why Governments Can't Be Trusted with Health Crises
description: The latest health crisis has made it clear that governments put their own interests before those of the public while hiding crucial information and imposing counterproductive regulations.

title: In Spain You Can't Use Your Own Back Yard. Police Make Sure of It.
description: Philipp Bagus reports from Spain: when people are frightened enough, they'll let the state do pretty much anything.

title: The European Central Bank Is Being Stretched to Its Breaking Point in Italy
description: At this point, monetary policy can't save Italy. Promises from Europe's central bank have allowed Italian policymakers to avoid coming to terms with Italy's bankrupt reality. Until now.

title: Why We Need Free Markets To Fight Pandemics
description: What needs to be done in such a crisis is not to attempt to steer the market to ensure it provides what is needed, but to let it free to do what it always does: match the goals of entrepreneurial producers with the needs of the populace.

title: The Chinese Regime Has Made China's Woes Much Worse
description: Whether we're talking public health or economic growth, the Chinese regime's love of intervention and centralization has led to one crisis after another.

title: Keynes: The Young Imperialist, 1906–13
description: Between 1909 and 1913, Keynes was the most important defender of British monetary imperialism in India. His faithful defense of the British Empire in those early years allowed him to become the century’s most influential economist after the war.

title: Coronavirus Panic: From Trillion-Dollar Paternalism to "Cash for Bunkers"
description: You are not even allowed to ask: "Is the price we’re paying worth it?" or "Is this an abundance of caution, or an overdose?" The "serious people" attack anyone who urges calm and encourages others to adopt a "don’t panic" approach. The new party line is: panic = virtue.

title: Fail: Quantitative Methods Presume That Human Action Is Reflexive
description: Quantitative methods can't be applied to human action, which is purposeful and not a mere reflex. For this reason, mathematical formulas can only describe events, never explain them.

title: A Fallacy about Negative Externalities
description: Some people use the concept of negative externalities to argue for government to force people toward "what is best for them." An example of this is the call for a consumption tax.

title: A Fallacy about Negative Externalities
description: Some people use the concept of negative externalities to argue for government to force people toward "what is best for them." An example of this is the call for a consumption tax.

title: Even When They're Wrong, We Can Learn From Understanding Others' Theories
description: Learning the history of economic thought is important not because every economist has been right, but because we can learn from their mistakes.

title: The Fed Is a One-Trick Pony
description: Printing up paper money—which is the Fed's solution to nearly everything—will not bring about a miraculous replacement of the lost goods and services or repair broken supply chains.

title: No, Technology Shocks Aren't Behind Recurring Business Cycles
description: Finn Kydland and Edward C. Prescott (KP), the 2004 Nobel laureates in economics think that technological shocks can explain 70 percent of economic fluctuations in postwar US data. Unfortunately their quantitative methods are simplistic and ignore the real problem: central banking.

title: The Global Economy Won't Bounce Back Soon
description: It is very likely that the shutdown of major developed economies will be followed by a shutdown of emerging markets, creating a supply shock as we have not seen in decades.

title: Financialization: Why the Financial Sector Now Rules the Global Economy
description: "Financialization" is the process by which a normal economy is transformed into a fragile economy centered around financial firms. Central banks and government bailouts are to blame.

title: After Brexit, the Timing of the Coronavirus Couldn't Be Worse for EU Bureaucrats
description: Eurocrats might be able to get tables in their favoured restaurants more easily while national governments take it on the chin. But this is a temporary situation which could easily evolve into a threat against the union.

title: Government Is No Match for the Coronavirus
description: The coronavirus crisis must cause us to rethink the idea governments can manage these situations. It is absolutely true that most private industry can be trusted, because the alternative for poor or unscrupulous providers is failure.

title: Japanization: 30 Years of Failed Economic "Stimulus"
description: Real wages in Japan have been declining thanks to decades of expansionary monetary and fiscal policies. Now "Japanization" increasingly looks like a fate that awaits Europe.

title: The Fed Has Sufficient Tools—to Wreck the Economy
description: These famed "tools" of the central bank are nothing but cunning and arcane techniques for conjuring additional trillions of dollars out of thin air and pumping them into the global economy.

title: War On China?
description: Sinister forces in American political life are using the coronavirus crisis to incite war with China and to stir up bad feelings toward the Chinese people. But war with China should be the last thing people want.

title: Coronavirus: The EU Is No Longer a Border-Free Zone for Member Countries
description: As the member states of the EU begin to shut their internal borders to their neighbors, we're reminded that state-to-state open borders in a place like the US do come with a downside.

title: The Fed Has Sufficient Tools—to Wreck the Economy
description: These famed "tools" of the central bank are nothing but cunning and arcane techniques for conjuring additional trillions of dollars out of thin air and pumping them into the global economy.

title: Politicians Are Calling for Lots of "Bold" Plans. Watch Out.
description: With both major political parties seemingly uninterested in the long-term fiscal stability of the United States, the only near-term solution for the spendthrift class in Washington, DC, is to either raise taxes or spend recklessly.

title: Could the Coronavirus Be Fatal for the EU?
description: As the nation-states take the brunt of their economic collapses on the chin, they will begin to realise that the EU superstate is little more than an obstructive and costly irrelevance.

title: The Fed’s Massive Injection of "Liquidity" Also Benefits Uncle Sam
description: By announcing that it is willing to throw up to $1.5 trillion in electronically created money  in order to give three-month loans to those institutions that bought Treasury debt earlier, the Fed is bailing out not only the holders of Treasury debt, but also the Treasury itself.

title: Bernie's Socialism vs. Trump's Socialism
description: If he were honest, rather than declaring that "America will never be a socialist country," Trump would simply say, "my socialism is better than Bernie's socialism."

title: Why "Social" Entrepreneurship Is No Substitute for "Market" Entrepreneurship
description: Market entrepreneurship is what generates net value in society, whereas social entrepreneurship is primarily the use of that value.

title: Left and Right, Many Are Turning toward De Facto Secession—and That's Not a Bad Thing
description: Remember how election day used to be a day of national relief, no matter who won? Regular people were happy that our political warring was over for a while, at least. But we don't live in that country anymore.

title: Logic and the Disutility of Labor
description: Choosing between labor and leisure is not like choosing between apples and oranges. Many people like both kinds of fruit. But labor involves disutility, so a better choice is this: between apples and rotten oranges.

title: Logic and the Disutility of Labor
description: Choosing between labor and leisure is not like choosing between apples and oranges. Many people like both kinds of fruit. But labor involves disutility, so a better choice is this: between apples and rotten oranges.

title: Modern Monetary Theory Is an Old Marxist Idea
description: Modern monetary theory (MMT) conveniently facilitates dangerous policies and ideas that seemed unrealistic, like universal basic income and “helicopter money,” and that have been particularly propagated by government-sponsored economists for the past few years.

title: Socialist Destructionism
description: Socialism is not the pioneer of a better and finer world, but the spoiler of what thousands of years of civilization have created. It does not build; it destroys.

title: The Coronavirus Won't Be the Cause of the Next Bust, but It Will Make It Worse
description: Although shocks can disrupt the pace of economic activity, they have nothing to do with the phenomenon of recurrent boom-bust cycles. The cycle requires something more. A central bank, for instance.

title: Greater Idaho Movement Is the Latest Indicator of a Shift toward Decentralization
description: Recently disgruntled residents of rural counties in southwest Oregon have been organizing a petition to move Idaho’s border westward to form a “Greater Idaho” that could also potentially include parts of Northern California.

title: Will More Easy Money Strengthen the Ailing Economy?
description: Lower interest rates won't make an economy grow. What matters is real savings.

title: Why Medicare for All Would Require Huge Tax Increases
description: Medicare for All advocates claim they are increasing access to medical services. But the plan mostly just increases demand without increasing supply. The "solution" comes later with price caps, tax hikes, and shortages.

title: The CDC's Budget Is Larger Now Than under Obama
description: Many left-wing pundits and politicians are claiming that the Centers for Disease Control budget was "gutted" in recent years. But the CDC's budget is now higher than it was in the final years of the Obama administration.

title: Let's Give Bernie-Syle Socialism a Try in California First
description: For starters, let's have California secede and limit Bernie-style socialism to the new republic. If my predictions ended up being wrong and the state became a paradise, then the rest of the country could quickly follow suit.

title: If China Is the Problem, Can't We at Least Have Free Trade with Everyone Else?
description: Protectionists think China is a geopolitical threat. I get that. But their (weak) arguments about China don't apply at all to the rest of the world.

title: The "Market Monetarists" and NGDP Targeting
description: A relatively new challenge to the Austrian framework comes from the “market monetarists” and their endorsement of a central bank policy of “level targeting” of nominal gross domestic product.

title: Entrepreneurs Flourish Most Where There Is a Culture and History of Entrepreneurship
description: Governments that hamper entrepreneurship certainly damage it in the near term. But these measures destroy the conditions necessary for innovation and entrepreneurship in the future as well.

title: Mexico's Leftist Leader Is Turning Out To Be a Disaster
description: The last sixteen months of López Obrador's administration have been a show of incompetence, yet people continue to cling to the idea that the key to solving Mexico's problems is getting the "right people" in office.

title: What Comes after Quantitative Easing?
description: What we observe today is a desperate fight against deflation. We know that this situation is unsustainable, but we do not know to which side the balloon will fall.

title: Why Sweden’s Negative Interest Rate Experiment Is a Failure
description: After years of negative rates, Sweden's central bank moves toward positive rates again. But this is setting the stage for an economic bust.

title: The Fed Panicked, and Its Rate Cut Is Making the Economy Worse
description: The Federal Reserve's monumental mistake of cutting rates this past week can only be understood in the context of the rising God complex of central planners: an overwhelming combination of ignorance and arrogance.

title: Rose Wilder Lane Is Now More Relevant Than Ever
description: Rose Wilder Lane was one of the past century's most ardent proponents of liberty. Give Me Liberty, which traces her evolution from communism to a devotion to liberty, is as relevant to the present as it was in 1936.

title: California Heads toward Disaster with Yet Another Rent Control Ballot Measure
description: Rent control looks good in the short run, but over time it means less housing and higher real costs for most ordinary people.

title: The Oakland Raiders Spike the Ball on Nevada Taxpayers
description: The departed Al Davis, who owned the Oakland Raiders, was famous for saying, “Just win, baby.” But now the team's philosophy is this: “Just raid the taxpayers, baby.”

title: The Myth of National Guilt
description: If we insist on "collective" responsibility assigned to entire nations, then we must naturally punish the innocent along with the guilty.

title: Why Deflation Can Be a Good Thing
description: Brazilian journalist André de Godoy interviews economist and Mises Institute scholar Antony Mueller on the nature of money, banking, and prices.

title: The Myth of National Guilt
description: If we insist on "collective" responsibility assigned to entire nations, then we must naturally punish the innocent along with the guilty.

title: The IRS's History of Attacking Political Dissenters and Opponents
description: Since politicians increasingly use tax law as a means of regulating American life, the IRS has become a supercharged regulatory organization that goes far beyond just collecting taxes.

title: "Heritage" Designation of Old Buildings Is Both Wasteful and Arbitrary
description: After an old red barn was given "heritage protection" by the city council, the owner demolished it anyway. Many townspeople cheered the defiance of the council's blatant violation of property rights.

title: What Would Murray Say About the Coronavirus?
description: If government scientists claim that they have discovered a vaccine for the coronavirus, can the government force us to take it? Can they force us into quarantines? These are the sort of problems we can solve if we look to Murray for help.

title: The US Constitution Needs an Expiration Date
description: The Swiss constitution wisely puts a "date of expiration" on the central government's taxing power every 10-15 years. Voters have to vote "yes" to extend this power. Americans should demand something similar, both for taxes and for much more.

title: Governments Are Using the Coronavirus to Distract from Their Own Failures
description: The coronavirus impact adds to an already weak and bloated global economy that was showing poor growth, high debt, and an evidently disappointing earnings season before any epidemic was included in estimates.

title: Christine Lagarde’s New Vision for the ECB
description: Although consensus building surely is an important and noble pursuit, one would think that it wouldn't really fall within the purview of a central bank president. It’s been clear for a long time that allowing politics to influence monetary policy carries significant and numerous risks.

title: "Political Anarchy" Is How the West Got Rich
description: Why did Europe go from a poor backwater to an economic and technological powerhouse? A major factor was its lack of any centralized government, and a large number of small competing states.

title: Coronavirus: Central Banks Stand Ready with More "Stimulus"
description: There are echoes of the 1973 oil shock in the current virus scare and resulting economic seize-up. Central banks are likely to respond similarly: with "stimulus" and inflation.

title: Coronavirus: Central Banks Stand Ready with More "Stimulus"
description: There are echoes of the 1973 oil shock in the current virus scare and resulting economic seize-up. Central banks are likely to respond similarly: with "stimulus" and inflation.

title: The Fed Slashes Rates as Powell Declares Economy "Strong"
description: Today's rate cut of 50 basis points is the largest rate cut since December 2008, in the midst of the aftermath of the financial crisis. But Chairman Powell insists the US economy is "strong."

title: Trump Is Trying to Ride the Pentagon Gravy Train to Reelection
description: Trump is spinning a narrative in which ever larger government budgets—and ever larger piles of deficit spending—create jobs and make America "safe."

title: How Government Spending Destroys Wealth
description: Government spending overall—not just deficits—is the real problem. Government spending diverts wealth away from truly productive people and toward the government and its favored groups.

title: Is the Fed Ready for a Recession?
description: By being so dovish for so long, the Fed has greatly limited what it can do in case of recession without resorting to untried and radical solutions like negative rates.

title: American Socialism Isn't Marxism—but It's Still a Problem
description: To effectively counter this brand of American socialism, it is important to properly identify the problem, and to attack with precision.

title: Some State Governments Are Actually Trying to Scale Back Their Regulatory Bureaucracy
description: Unlike in the federal government, some small bits of progress have been made against the regulatory regime at the state level

title: To Adopt Keynesian Terminology Is to Legitimize It
description: Ludwig von Mises discusses inflation, labor unions, and issues of the adoption of improper terminology and widespread public misinformation at the Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Princeton, New Jersey, on September 11, 1958.

title: Money Supply Growth Climbs to 36-Month High
description: During January 2020, year-over-year (YOY) growth in the money supply was at 6.32 percent. That's up from December's rate of 5.53 percent, and up from January 2019's rate of 3.38 percent.

title: Why Don't Pro-Tax Millionaires Just Pay More Tax Voluntarily?
description: Many rich people publicly support measures to "raise taxes on the rich." This is because the cost of voting to give away $1 million is far lower than the cost of actually giving it away.

title: Popper and the Course of History
description: Can a scientific law allow us to predict the course of history? Marxists lean in this direction, but Karl Popper says it's impossible. Is he right?

title: Fed-Driven Asset Price Inflation Means You Can Now Buy Less House Than You Could Before
description: Central banks are driving asset price inflation in stocks and real estate. That means people holding those assets get richer. But everyone else just gets higher prices.

title: Don't Forget About the Trade War
description: Trump clearly views trade in a zero-sum, mercantilist manner, with the country possessing a deficit “losing” and “down.” But continuing the trade war only makes recession more likely for both sides. Luckily China is stalling on committing to a trade agreement.

title: The US's "Free Trade" Isn't Very Free
description: Whether we're talking about the Trump years or not, the idea that the United States embraces unconditional free trade at all costs—while being victimized by foreign protectionists—is based on fantasy.

title: The EU's Latest Screw-You to the UK Shows a Big Problem with Trade Agreements
description: Most "free trade" agreements are really just ways to expand the regulatory state and rob the consumers of the benefits they might have gotten from actual free trade.

title: The Entrepreneurial Advantages of Building Human Capital While Young
description: Everything you learned from family dinner conversations and your culture served to build your human capital. Across the globe, the people of various regions cultivate certain skills that enable individuals to consider entrepreneurship as a viable choice of work.

title: Four Reasons Inequality Isn’t What You Think It Is
description: Markets are not the enemy of equality. Regulated markets are. The income inequality that naturally occurs in the free market as a result of human uniqueness is needlessly amplified by restrictive government policies to the detriment of all.

title: Henry Hazlitt on Longines Chronoscope
description: Henry Hazlitt cohosted the CBS series Longines Chronoscope from June 16, 1952. The series ran from 1951–55 and featured notable people of the time.

title: Why Wall Street Bankers and Federal Lawyers Hate Michael Milken
description: Michael Milken was a threat to the complacent Wall Street cartels established by the New Deal. So ambitious prosecutors like Rudy Giuliani saw an opportunity to get in good with Wall Street by taking him down.

title: Pete Buttigieg's Sovietesque Plan for Rural Revitalization
description: Buttigieg's plan to repopulate depressed rural areas with immigrants reminds one of old Soviet schemes to ship people to Siberia to stimulate the economy there.

title: Central Banking since the 2008 Financial Crisis
description: In the wake of the financial crisis of 2008, the Federal Reserve and other central banks around the world adopted new “tools” to influence economic activity in addition to its standard open market operations.

title: How Fractional Reserve Lending Makes Money Disappear
description: Because banks make unbacked "loans," they create new money that later disappears when repaid. If these loans are not renewed, economic depression sets in.

title: The WTO Is Both Irrelevant and Unnecessary
description: The World Trade Organization was not the reason global trade was liberalized in past decades. And now, even if such a thing were desirable, the WTO is in no position to force liberalization on countries like the US, China, or India. Thus, the WTO is both unnecessary and irrelevant.

title: Trump's Betrayal of Julian Assange
description: It is ironic that a president who has been the victim of so much deep state meddling has done the deep state’s bidding when it comes to Assange and Wikileaks. The deep state that Trump is serving by persecuting Assange is the same deep state that continues to plot his own ouster.

title: Mises and the "New Economics"
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics,
description: Economics today poses as a predictive discipline which fails to correctly predict anything; a prescriptive discipline which prescribes the wrong policies; and an empirical discipline which collects data but misses the point.

title: When It Comes to Raw Power, Few Have More of It Than Central Bankers
description: Anticapitalists often complain that people with more money exercise power over people with less money. Yet these same people seem oddly untroubled by the fact that central bankers can manipulate the money supply at any time to enrich themselves at everyone else's expense.

title: Tax Burdens, Per Capita Income, and Simpson’s Paradox
description: Is there a correlation between wealth and a higher tax burden? After, people like to say that more taxes mean more public services.

title: Individual Responsibility and Guilt
description: Susan Neiman contends Southerners need to acknowledge guilt for slavery, segregation, and lynching, and "work off" the past. But collective responsibility is a chimera, and a dangerous one at that.

title: Blago Is Free
description: Blago's real crime wasn't trying to sell a senate seat, if he did in fact try to do that. Rather his crime was that he refused to appoint the man Obama had picked as his successor in the Senate.

title: Why Rothbard Wanted "Radical Decentralization"
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics,
description: Secession and decentralization are good for two reasons: they move us toward a society with more individual freedom. And smaller, more decentralized societies are more economically free.

title: Is Free Market Economics Too "Ideological"?
description: Free market economics is often ignorantly dismissed for being "ideological" rather than scientific. It probably sounds smart to the economically illiterate, but it is decidedly not.

title: Why It's so Hard to Escape America's "Anti-Poverty" Programs
description: Between the regulation of business and penalties for rising income, anti-poverty policies in America make it so that many workers have no clear path to escape poverty.

title: Nationalism as National Liberation: Lessons from the End of the Cold War
description: If we regard nationalism as necessarily harmful, we end up supporting the Soviet Union, and every empire and two-bit dictator who manages to hammer together a variety of disparate groups under a single national banner.

title: Social Security Cannot Survive in Its Present Form
description: The Social Security program will have to be either inflated away with increasingly worthless dollars or Congress will have to intervene to cut benefits.

title: The Green Fatal Conceit: Why Physical Science Can’t Tell Us Proper Policy Goals
description: The so-called CLEAN Future Act is as poorly designed as its acronym. Like the Green New Deal, it consists of radical new spending proposals that the bill’s supporters would have liked for other reasons, and which aren’t even compatible.

title: Why Governments Hate Secession
description: States seek to perpetuate themselves by seizing more control of capital and human beings. Size makes this easier. And every regime would become a mega-state like China or the US if it could.

title: Some Problems with Worker Productivity Stats
description: Government statistics on worker productivity combine many errors of aggregation such as "average prices" and the total purchasing power of money. So it's unlikely that productivity numbers tell us much that's useful.

title: How Chile's Protesters Get Inequality and Poverty Wrong
description: Allowing the market to operate with minimal government intervention has helped Chile become one of the freest and wealthiest countries in South America, especially when compared to its direct neighbors.

title: Social Security Is a Terrible "Investment"
description: Social Security has been a money-losing mess for decades, and it's a major drain on private sector saving and investment.

title: Bernie Sanders's Long History of Pushing Government Takeovers of Private Markets
description: The term "socialism" properly refers to government ownership of industry and service providers. In this respect, Bernie Sanders has a long record of proving he's a true socialist.

title: Socialism: A Brief Taxonomy
description: From orthodox Marxism to anarcho-syndicalism, here's a brief guide to the many flavors of socialism.

title: 3 Reasons Why More Secession Means More Freedom
description: Antisecessionists insist that radical decentralization means more "nationalism" and protectionism. In practice, the exact opposite is more likely.

title: Coerced Confessions: How the Plea Bargain Replaced Physical Torture
description: When the government created public police forces one hundred years ago, they often relied on torture to extract confessions. But now they have new methods: threatening to pile on new charges until the defendant takes a plea agreement.

title: Wicksteed on Surplus Value
description: Many people are familiar with Eugen von Bőhm-Bawerk's damning critique of Marx, but Philip Wicksteed also took the time to show where Marx had gone wrong and struck his surplus theory of value a fatal blow.

title: Government "Fixes" for the Trade Balance Are Worse Than Any Trade Deficit
description: The national trade account balance is of little economic significance and is a sterile concept. But the government’s attempts to "fix" it can have many harmful effects.

title: What Margit von Mises Loved Most About Ludwig
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics
description: Margit von Mises wanted her husband to be remembered for his humanity as much as his wisdom.

title: Rothbard: The Constitution Was a Coup d'État
description: Rothbard took the American Revolution to be mainly libertarian in its inspiration, but he contends that the libertarian impulses of the Revolution were betrayed by a centralizing coup d’état. If Rothbard is right, the Constitution as written provides ample scope for tyranny.

title: Foreign Aid Empowers Corrupt Regimes. End It.
description: US aid to foreign regimes helps free governments from having to raise funds from their own people. So, the recipients of foreign aid are likely to become less responsive and more corrupt.

title: US Mandatory Spending Projected to Increase Over a Trillion Dollars by 2023
description: Even if discretionary spending stays flat, total government outlays are estimated to increase by more than $1 trillion, significantly above any measure of tax revenues. And that is without considering a possible recession.

title: China's Economic Schemes Hurt the Chinese Most of All
description: Like Trump, I want China to stop manipulating its economy. But not for the same reasons Trump does.

title: US Mandatory Spending Projected to Increase Over a Trillion Dollars by 2023
description: Even if discretionary spending stays flat, total government outlays are estimated to increase by more than $1 trillion, significantly above any measure of tax revenues. And that is without considering a possible recession.

title: Why Entrepreneurs Miss Market Opportunities
description: Consumers are unpredictable, so it's very easy to miss important entrepreneurial opportunities. Entrepreneurship isn't as easy as it looks.

title: The Truth about The Edge of Democracy
description: The Edge of Democracy, a new Oscar-nominated documentary about Brazil, gets even basic facts wrong in pushing the idea that Brazil's corrupt and socialist politicians were the saviors of Brazilian democracy.

title: Small Countries Are Better: They're Often Richer and Safer Than Big Countries
description: Smaller countries have often been shown to perform better than large countries in terms of overall income and in economic growth. Also, their populations often enjoy more healthy and safe social environments.

title: Standard Open Market Operations: How the Fed and Commercial Banks "Create Money"
description: Robert Murphy defines some of the conventional “monetary aggregates,” such as M1 and M2, and gives the textbook rundown of how the Federal Reserve and commercial banking system “create money” when the Fed buys assets and the commercial banks extend new loans.

title: Europe Can't Afford a New "Green Deal"
description: As H. L. Mencken wrote, “For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong.” The EU's Green Deal is the latest example.

title: Humans Have Goals. And They Value Goods and Services Accordingly.
description: A given goal dictates the specific means that an individual will choose for the attainment of that end. People make choices that they think will help them achieve an end.

title: Private Sector Truck Drivers Are Nepal's Lifeline to Clean Water
description: Government officials have repeatedly failed to deliver clean water to the people of Kathmandu. So the private sector stepped in to get the job done.

title: The Economy Is Not a Factory—Nor Should We Try to Make It One
description: The economy is not primarily about the adjustment of capital investment across industries and firms, but about the determination of which industries and types of production will exist—and who will be involved in this future production.

title: Socialism Always Fails
description: To a socialist socialism is a moral imperative, and the only thing holding back the implementation of this system in the US has been the failure of socialists to present a plausible alternative—something that socialists claim now is being done.

title: The Fight for Liberty and the Beltway Barbarians
description: Are we emphasizing “the negative”? In a sense, yes, but what else are we to stress when our values, our principles, our very being are under attack from a relentless foe?

title: Why Open Borders Between States in America Might Lead to Disaster
description: The lack of state-to-state border controls has often served as an excuse to increase federal regulation of all states in the name of "uniform" laws. We've seen this with guns, drugs, alcohol, and migrants.

title: What Is Aggression?
description: Is just aiding and abetting someone in committing an aggressive act a violation of the nonaggression principle? What if you were "just" driving the getaway car?

title: We Need More Housing, Not More Rent Control
description: Blinded by their zeal to save the masses from the "excesses" of greedy landlords, politicians are ignoring the regulatory state that keeps housing prices on the rise.

title: This Austrian Legal Scholar Thought Case Law Was the Key to Limiting State Power
description: For Eugen Ehrlich, case law—as opposed to legislative law—could be be an effective tool in limiting state power and returning power to nonstate institutions.

title: Intellectual Property: Innovation Should Serve Consumers, Not Producers
description: Innovations aren't very useful unless they serve consumers in the marketplace. Otherwise, we're pursuing innovation for its own sake, and that isn't progress.

title: What’s Next for the Virginia Sanctuary Movement?
description: The protest movements by gun-ownership-rights activists in Virginia still faces an uphill battle. But it may be the best battle to choose, since it would be a mistake to put faith in the courts.

title: Brexit Voters Aren't As "Irrational" As Their Opponents Think
description: Some anti-Brexit pundits tried to frame the Brexit debate as one of savvy economics-minded people against economic illiterates. These people missed the point.

title: What Year Did Healthcare Become a "Right"?
description: Was healthcare a natural right two hundred years ago? If so, how is it that this "right" to eighteenth-century medicine morphed into a right to MRIs and chemotherapy? Do rights change with technology? That's not how rights work.

title: Shhhh: Repo Operation in Process
description: These days, the commercial banking system isn’t where the action is. Instead, it’s the shadow banking system that needs direct feeding to goose inflation—at least inflation in asset prices, and also to keep the debt service on the nation’s debt as low as possible.

title: South Korea’s Neo-Mercantilist Growth Engine Has Stalled
description: After very quickly becoming an advanced economy, South Korea is experiencing declining growth and labor productivity. The culprit, as usual, is government intervention in the market to favor certain interests.

title: Do People Really Seek to Maximize Profit?
description: Economics is not intent upon pronouncing value judgments. It aims at a cognition of the consequences of certain modes of acting.

title: And Rightly So: The Wisdom of Neil McCaffrey
description: Lew Rockwell reviews a newly released collection of Neil McCaffrey's letters and other writings, which reveal his relationships with members of the early libertarian movement such as Murray Rothbard.

title: How Keynesian Ideas Weaken Economic Fundamentals
description: There is productive consumption and there is non-productive consumption. In the Keynesian mind, it's not necessary to produce anything, so long as people spend and consume endlessly, even to the point of destroying real wealth.

title: "Disabled" Cop Fleeces Taxpayers While Working Full-Time for FBI
description: Taxpayers are paying the disability pension of a "disabled" former cop who works full-time for the FBI and is classified as being in "excellent physical condition."

title: Brexit: Predictions of Economic Doom Show Why People Ignore "Experts"
description: Experts who predicted economic doom as Brexit approached obsessed over the problem of "transaction costs" in trade. But the EU was imposing countless new transaction costs of its own.

title: The State Owns You: The Problem with "National Service"
description: All arguments in favor of mandatory service rest on the idea that an individual's life belongs not to him- or herself, but to the state.

title: Why Voting Doesn't Tell Us What Voters Really Want
description: In a large enough democracy, the impact of an individual vote is statistically zero on the margin.

title: Nomi Prins: Repo Injections Are QE by Another Name
description: The Fed's balance sheet has risen to $4.1 trillion from $3.7 trillion in August. Nomi Prins discusses what this policy shift means and what it portends for 2020.

title: Your Rational Self vs. Your Irrational Self
description: How can paternalists say that when they make it more difficult for you to smoke they aren’t interfering with your freedom? They've come up with a bizarre rationale.

title: Nomi Prins: Repo Injections Are QE by Another Name
description: The Fed's balance sheet has risen to $4.1 trillion from $3.7 trillion in August. Nomi Prins discusses what this policy shift means and what it portends for 2020.

title: The Age of Entitlement: The Legacy of Anti-Discrimination Laws
description: The task that civil rights laws were meant to carry out—the top-down management of various ethnic, regional, and social groups—had always been the main task of empires. The US now imposes this both domestically and globally.

title: Why Democracy Doesn't Give Us What We Want
description: Uncritically holding democracy out as an ideal overlooks the question of whether market democracy or political democracy better serves citizens.

title: The State Is a Predator. It Can't Be Used to Achieve Libertarian Ends
description: In portraying the state as an integral part of economy and society, advocates of "state capacity libertarianism" ignore the state's unique political, i.e., predatory, nature.

title: Protectionism Is Not the Answer to the Canadian Fur Trade’s Problems
description: The North American fur trade is in decline. Unfortunately, many think that the solution is for the government to step in to “protect” trappers from market competition.

title: Franz Jägerstätter: Conscientious Objector
description: Terrence Malick's new film about conscientious objector Franz Jägerstätter is a subtle film. But perhaps too much so, and we need to look deeper to understand why this one man so vehemently resisted the Nazi state at the cost of his own life.

title: Savings vs. Money: Which Is More Important?
description: It is not money that funds economic activity, but the saved pool of consumer goods. The existence of money only facilitates the flow of savings. Any attempt to replace savings with money ends in economic disaster.

title: The Theory and Brief History of Money and Banking
description: Why do we have money in the first place? Where does it come from, and what determines its form? What qualities make for a good money? What role do banks play—is it something other than what money itself does for us?

title: Markets Provide Guns Despite Government Restrictions
description: In spite of all kinds of restrictions and red tape, consumer demand for firearms remains high, and the industry has found a way to meet that demand—through "80 percent lower receivers."

title: The True Costs of Bad Economists, Explained
description: In terms of economics, what currently is should be of very little importance: what matters, and that we should seek to understand, is the process that brought it about and that will create what will be in its place.

title: The Folly of Economic "Stabilization"
description: Shortcomings in the government's handling of monetary matters, of credit expansion, and the disastrous consequences of lowering the rate of interest gave birth to the ideas which finally generated the slogan "stabilization."

title: The Medicaid Expansion Cheat
description: Proponents of Medicaid expansion pioneered new ways of covering up the true costs of a government program.

title: After November Surge, Money Supply Growth Slows in December
description: During December 2019, year-over-year growth in the money supply was at 5.53 percent. That's down from November's rate of 5.9 percent, but was up from December 2018's rate of 3.90 percent.

title: "Surveillance Capitalism": A Summary of Critics
description: There's a new kind of capitalism on the scene: "surveillance capitalism." It's drawn attention from across the political spectrum, but Left, Right, and center offer very different solutions to similar concerns.

title: Argentina’s "Emergency Law" Just Means More of the Same
description: Argentina is only going to prosper when it recognizes that its fiscal and monetary imbalances are not the fault of the citizens and their small businesses, but of the government.

title: Pseudo-Psychiatrist "Diagnoses" Trump Supporters with Mental Disorders
description: The great libertarian psychiatrist Thomas Szasz warned that health officials could use their "expertise" to push a political agenda. We're now living in that world.

title: Secession in Virginia Would Defuse the State's Conflict over Guns
description: If opponents of the current ideological winds blowing in Virginia find themselves in a permanent minority, it may very well be that the only method of defending the minority position is by leaving the state. But "exit" can theoretically be obtained in more than one way.

title: Hegel's Very Odd Definition of Freedom
description: Liberalism conceives of freedom as the absence of constraint, but Hegel's definition is more expansive. And, of course, the state is a necessary condition for it.

title: What We Really Mean When We Talk About Values and Prices in the Marketplace
description: Values of goods are not static things that can be used for central planning. Values apply only to a particular transaction at a particular place and at a given time by human beings.

title: Meet the Spendthrifts
description: If the government were a sitcom family, they would be called the Spendthrifts, and no one would dream of trusting them with credit.

title: Why "One Man, One Vote" Doesn't Work
description: Efforts to abolish the US Senate because it's "undemocratic" employ a very crude and dangerous type of majoritarianism.

title: Meet the Spendthrifts
description: If the government were a sitcom family, they would be called the Spendthrifts, and no one would dream of trusting them with credit.

title: Why Bad GDP Metrics Lead to Bad Policy
description: Our flawed economic measure called GDP leads to a flawed and skewed view of the economy in which consumer spending is the most important metric.

title: Peaceful Market Exchange—Not Politics—Harnesses the Value of Diversity
description: Whether diversity is a social benefit depends on whether it creates excuses to fight each other for special treatment. Politicizing our differences is far more likely to make diversity a source of conflict.

title: The Majority of Virginia Homicides Come from Only Two Metro Areas
description: Just two metro areas in Virginia reported more homicides than all the rest of the state combined.

title: Fed Nominee Judy Shelton Wants Sound Money—and Lots of It
description: Judy Shelton may be a tolerable—at least to Republicans—candidate for the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

title: The Limits of Economic Calculation
description: It is possible to determine in terms of money prices the sum of the income or the wealth of a number of people. But it is nonsensical to reckon national income or national wealth.

title: How to Avoid Secular Stagnation
description: In order to remove the threat of secular stagnation what is required is to shrink government outlays and to close all the loopholes for the creation of money out of thin air.

title: A World Without Entrepreneurs
description: Entrepreneurs are the reason consumers have come to expect new gains and innovations in products and services every year. Without entrepreneurs, we'd still be using rotary phones.

title: Are Housing Markets Still Clearing Out the Trash of the Last Bust?
description: Many mortgages have not just been modified once, but twice, and sometimes more. Loan servicers are holding higher-end mortgages rather than foreclosing a decade after the crash. Thus, there is plenty of shadow inventory lurking, waiting for the next crash.

title: Are Housing Markets Still Clearing Out the Trash of the Last Bust?
description: Many mortgages have not just been modified once, but twice, and sometimes more. Loan servicers are holding higher-end mortgages rather than foreclosing a decade after the crash. Thus, there is plenty of shadow inventory lurking, waiting for the next crash.

title: The Deception behind Government Licensing Laws
description: How much licensing requirements are designed to “protect” the health of the public, and how much to restrict competition, may be gauged from the fact that giving medical advice free without a license is rarely a legal offense. Only the sale of medical advice requires a license.

title: What Free Market Money Would Look Like
description: Monetary affairs have always been subject to government intervention of one kind or another, but there is no reason money could not be produced and regulated in a free marketplace.

title: California's Anti-Self-Employment Law Is Already Crushing Freelancers
description: State lawmakers possess an infinite source of good intentions. Wielding the power of this limitless benevolence and munificence, politicians are regulating the lives of citizens while eviscerating their existence in the process.

title: Luck and Taxes
description: Some argue that someone’s superior talent or success is itself the result of mere luck. That claim, and its relevance as a justification for redistribution, has generated much controversy.

title: The Bank of England's Governor Fears a Liquidity Trap
description: The demand for goods is not constrained by the amount of money, but by the production of goods and services available to trade for money.

title: Death to Prohibition
description: The repeated failure of prohibition may be just the catalyst that Austrian economics needs to gain traction with the American public.

title: What Will It Take to Get the Public to Embrace Sound Money?
description: If the small sample size of monetary history is any guide, the combination of asset market crashes and high goods inflation empowers sound money forces in the political arena. At the moment, neither of those factors are in play.

title: A Limited-Government Republic versus a National-Security State
description: What is a national-security state? It is a totalitarian-like governmental structure that consists of an enormous military-intelligence establishment with extraordinary powers, such as indefinite detention, torture, secret surveillance, and even assassination of both citizens and foreigners.

title: The World Looks to Abandon the Dollar as US Sanctions Tighten Their Grip
description: The US's enthusiasm for sanctions means Europe is learning the price of doing business with the United States and with the dollar.  They're now developing new ways to work around the the US-dominated financial system.

title: The European Green Deal Is Every Bit as Bad as Expected
description: While the legislation introduced in the US Congress remains fiction under a Republican executive and senate, the Brussels initiative will become law unless there is considerable opposition from EU member states.

title: An Austrian Frame of Mind
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics,
description: The Marginal Revolutionaries: How Austrian Economists Fought the War of Ideas is a lively history of the astonishing influence prewar Viennese intellectuals had on the greater world, and continue to have in areas far beyond economics.

title: Understanding Money Mechanics: A Crash Course on the Fed
description: Economist Robert Murphy lays out the purpose and structure of his upcoming book Understanding Money Mechanics, a guide to the Federal Reserve System that is a must-read for laymen. It will be released as a bimonthly serial on the Mises Wire and then published as a book.

title: Economic Freedom Reduced Inequality in Chile. But the Left Has Other Plans.
description: If Chileans are concerned about inequality, real solutions are likely to be found in combating the central bank and other anti-market institutions.

title: Subprime Loans Will Be Back with a Vengeance in 2020
description: After lying dormant for several years in the aftermath of the Great Recession, the subprime market has returned with a vengeance. Subprime has become prevalent in every facet of the credit industry, and we should be terrified.

title: Huge Debt Got Us Hooked on Petrodollars — and on Saudi Arabia
description: Petrodollars and petrodollar recycling are at the heart of what keeps the US debt and money-printing mechanism going. The geopolitical stakes are very high.

title: More Money Creation Won't Create More Economic Growth
description: Contrary to the popular way of thinking, setting in motion a consumption unbacked by production through monetary pumping will only stifle economic growth.

title: The Federal "Crimes" of the College Admission Scandal Aren't Real Crimes
description: All of the “crimes” tied to this case are essentially fictional charges that are derived from some other action. These are "derivative crimes," based on invented violations such as "false statements" or "obstructing the mails."

title: The History and Structure of the Federal Reserve System
description: The original justification for the creation of another central bank did not allude to the modern goals of “full employment” and “price stability.” Rather, the pleas of the time called for an “elastic currency” that would expand or contract according to the “needs of trade.”

title: Universal Basic Income: A Dream Come True for Despots
description: A universal basic income can easily be weaponized as a tool to punish "antisocial" behavior such as holding "unacceptable" political views or otherwise engaging in what the state doesn't like.

title: Universal Basic Income: A Dream Come True for Despots
description: A universal basic income can easily be weaponized as a tool to punish "antisocial" behavior such as holding "unacceptable" political views or otherwise engaging in what the state doesn't like.

title: The Many Ways Governments Create Monopolies
description: Since outright grants of monopoly or quasi-monopoly would usually be considered baldly injurious to the public, governments have discovered a variety of methods of granting such privileges indirectly, as well as a variety of arguments to justify these measures.

title: Economist: Your Freedom Is Dangerous Because You Might Set a Bad Example
description: Why should we think that government officials are better at acting “rationally” than those they regulate? Even if we were to concede that smoking deserves to be restricted, why should we think the government can do it in a reasonable way?

title: Conservatives Are Increasingly Wrong about Market Freedom
description: The conservative case against market freedom is based on the belief that if change disrupts the status quo in any way, or if companies impose cost reductions that result in a shifting of employment — or even some layoffs — then government should step in and take control.

title: President's Impact Report — Fourth Quarter 2019
description: See what we've accomplished this quarter! We are proud of our students, scholars, and events; and we strive for a higher standard in everything we do. Thank you to our Members who make all of this possible.

title: A Fearful Fed Keeps Pouring Money into the Repo Market
description: Repo markets aren't as liquid as the Fed wants. This could be due to immense amounts of new government debt, or because US Treasurys aren't as risk-free as many assume.

title: Post-Mugabe Zimbabwe Still Faces a Host of Economic Problems
description: Nothing short of an economic exorcism is needed in Zimbabwe. Looking at what President Mnangagwa has done so far, it doesn’t seem that Zimbabwe is actually serious about making tough reforms.

title: "Low" Tax Rates Often Mask Much Larger Tax Burdens
description: The moral of this economic story is that whenever someone who has an incentive to lowball the burden of a tax is speaking or writing, be careful to look at what happens to take-home income as a better guide to policy.

title: How Rent Seeking Impoverishes Nations
description: So long as governments exist, it is essential that we minimize the ability of groups and individuals to use the power of the state to enrich themselves.

title: Two Big Problems with Single-Payer Healthcare
description: Single-payer systems do indeed restrict access and quality. They just do it by imposing long wait times, cutting off costlier patients, and restricting access to hospital rooms.

title: If Trump Decides to Start a Nuclear War, No One Can (Legally) Stop Him
description: There's no evidence Trump is more trigger-happy than any other president, but the presidency's unchecked nuclear-launch power will remain a problem both now and with future presidents.

title: Investors, Randomness, and Entrepreneurial Thinking
description: It's possible for investors and entrepreneurs to make a lot of money in markets without understanding the economic theory behind their actions.

title: Why Sweden Ended Its Negative Interest Rate Experiment
description: Sweden launched its failed negative rate plan almost five years ago and now reverses it due to the financial risks that are created.

title: Money Supply Growth Surged to a 33-Month High in November
description: During November 2019, year-over-year growth in the money supply was at 6.22 percent. That's up from October's rate of 4.93 percent, and from November 2018's rate of 3.07 percent.

title: Henry Ford Did More for Workers than Unions Did
description: Henry Ford's factories had a hard time keeping workers because the work was monotonous. So Ford helped keep workers around through reduced hours, vacation time, and other benefits that are now considered typical.

title: Now Is the Time to De-Escalate War with Iran
description: The Iraqi parliament response to the recent US airstrike — expelling all US troops from Iraq — suggests that an escalation of the ongoing US-Iran conflict would not be as simple as pro-war factions of the US regime would like it to be.

title: Money, Expectations, and Economic Growth
