description: Even if the central bank policymakers could implement policies without error, Milton Friedman’s and Robert Lucas’s monetary schemes could not secure stable economic growth.

title: Conservation in the Free Market
description: One of the most disquieting features of the environmentalist movement is its evident abhorrence of modern technology and its Romanticist back-to-nature philosophy. Technology and civilization are responsible, they say, for crowding, pollution, despoliation of resources, so let us therefore return to unspoiled nature, to Walden Pond, to contemplation in a far-off glade. None of these critics of modern culture and civilization seem to realize that the back-to-nature path would not only mean shuffling off the benefits of civilization, but would also mean starvation and death for the vast bulk of mankind.

title: The Seen and the Unseen of "Waste"
description: When a farmer leaves some unharvested crops in the field, they are not "wasted." Real waste would be found in efforts to use up every last physical resource, no matter how costly those efforts might be.

title: Why Paternalists Keep Calling Us "Irrational"
description: Central planners like Cass Sunstein think our alleged "irrationality" means we need the government to intervene in our daily lives.

title: Why the US Wants to Lower Germans' Real Wages
description: The US government has placed sanctions on those who are building a natural gas pipeline from Russia to Europe.

title: The US's Latest Bombing Shows the US Lost the Iraq War
description: "To recognize that the Baghdadi government is an enemy of the United States is to acknowledge that not only was the Iraq war a mistake, but that its outcome was a boon for Iran."

title: Bernie Sanders Wants to Kill Pro Baseball
description: Major league baseball wants to cut back the minors in order to cut losses. But Bernie Sanders has other plans that may ultimately help kill pro baseball.

title: Why the Minimum Wage Is so Bad for Young Workers
description: Studies have shown that the amount of money paid in the low-wage labor market declined overall as a result of minimum wage hikes.

title: Hunter-Gatherers Ravaged the Environment. Industrialization Saved It.
description: Hunter-gatherer societies stripped the local environment of resources and then moved on to another place. There was nothing environmentally responsible about this sort of economy, in spite of modern efforts to portray prehistoric humans as tree huggers.

title: Butler Shaffer, RIP
description: Butler belongs in the pantheon of genuine heroes, along with his friends Murray Rothbard and Burt Blumert. Fortunately for us, another of those heroes, Butler’s friend Ron Paul, is still here to lead us and inspire us.

title: 2019 Was a Bad Year for the "Only Cops Should Have Guns" Narrative
description: From cops killing innocents in their living rooms to private citizens shooting down criminal gunmen, 2019 provided some highlights of why so many Americans choose to arm themselves rather than trust in government protection.

title: Economic Stats Won't Tell Us What Really Causes Recessions
description: The mainstream National Bureau of Economic Research definition of recessions is of little value. Real saving, not consumer demand, is the real driver behind economic growth.

title: New Year's Resolutions with F. A. Harper
description: "Truth has a power that cannot be touched by physical force. It is impossible to shoot a truth."

title: "Rules of Origin" Show Why Trade Agreements Aren't Free Trade
description: A “free trade agreement” in practice isn’t simply an index card declaring, “Tariffs on Country X are 0 percent, three cheers for Bastiat!” These are managed trade agreements, with hundreds of pages devoted to detailed regulations that smack of top-down Soviet planning.

title: Is China a Better Trading Partner for Latin America Than the US?
description: Some Latin American policymakers seem to think China will offer easy terms for loans and trade agreements. They're wrong. China isn't as rich as many think.

title: In Healthcare, a Little Bit of Market Freedom Goes a Long Way
description: Clearly marked prices on private-sector cash-payment surgeries are a great thing. In fact, the competition of for-profit surgery centers drives down prices at more "traditional" (i.e., highly bureaucratized) hospitals.

title: How to Write and Understand History
description: Economic history is possible only because there is an economic theory capable of throwing light upon economic actions. If there were no economic theory, reports concerning economic facts would be nothing more than a collection of unconnected data open to any arbitrary interpretation.

title: What an Independent Britain Could Learn from Singapore
description: Singapore left both the British Empire and Malaysia before finally becoming an independent city. It then proceeded to become one of history's most impressive economic success stories.

title: To Be Useful, Data Needs Theory
description: Statistical data is merely history, but a competent historian does not simply let the events speak for themselves. He arranges them according to the ideas underlying the general notions he uses in their presentation. He does not report facts as they happened, but only relevant facts.

title: Why the Drug War Makes Drugs More Potent
description: When governments raise the cost of obtaining a good, many people will opt for buying a higher quality (or more potent) version of the good with each transaction.

title: Why Marx Was against Individual Rights
description: Karl Marx agreed with Rothbard that individual rights lead to inequality. For Marx, though, this was an argument against rights.

title: Healthcare and "Market Failure"
description: Proponents of socialized medicine assert that markets cannot be trusted with healthcare due to "market failure." But the assumed "failures" of health markets are not improved by socializing healthcare.

title: The Battle in the War of Ideas
description: Our foremost mission is to fight back in the war of ideas, and we must.

title: What Is Capital?
description: In order to expand production and increase productivity — and thus increase the standard of living — it is necessary to use capital. And so it makes sense to pay interest on capital lent, so as to encourage the maintenance and production of capital for the future.

title: The Problem with Democracy? Letting Everyone Do It
description: We don’t let just anyone repair our homes or perform surgery. So why do we let everyone vote, and, theoretically, let just anyone rule? Jason Brennan’s recommendation is epistocracy: the rule of the knowledgeable.

title: This Christmas, Let's Celebrate a Different Scrooge: Scrooge McDuck
description: Scrooge McDuck is the perfect type of a miser: a capitalist-entrepreneur — and the most philanthropic man (duck, I mean) in Duckburg.

title: George Bailey, Capitalist Hero
description: In It's a Wonderful Life, George Bailey was right to oppose Old Man Potter. Potter's fondness for the draft board and his attempt to use the DA to crush his adversary shows Potter had little regard for truly voluntary exchange.

title: Successful Entrepreneurs Learn from a Constantly Changing Marketplace
description: Successful entrepreneurial strategy incorporates learning of all types from trial and error. What other choice is there for entrepreneurs, since they are not omniscient or omnipresent in market processes?

title: The Wealth Redistribution Scam that Is "Inflation"
description: As money loses its purchasing power, income and wealth are stealthily redistributed. Some individuals and groups of people are enriched at the expense of others.

title: Chile Is in Danger of Becoming Just Another Crisis-Ridden Latin American Country
description: Axel Kaiser writes that Chileans’ “advantage is due to an historical accident, which is now coming to an end” and predicted that “Chile will show, in the coming years, that it is nothing more than any other Latin-American country.”

title: How Today's Central Bankers Threaten Civilization
description: Our monetary system, combined with interventionist state policies, causes mass overconsumption, the destruction of wealth, capital consumption, and the destruction of nature.

title: Abolish the Office of the First Lady
description: Once upon a time, the president was expected to pay for parties and public relations out of his own pocket. Now we have the Office of the First Lady, so taxpayers can now pay her staff to plan opulent parties for wealthy donors and powerful politicians at the White House.

title: Three Arguments Debunking Marx’s Labor Theory of Value
description: As dismissive as many of us would like to be toward Marx’s thoroughly debunked labor theory of value, it still holds currency among today’s budding socialists.

title: Elizabeth Warren Shouldn't Be So Proud that Her Big Plans Are Already "Paid For"
description: Politicians are very proud when they can say a proposed program is "paid for." But this only means they've identified their intended victims ahead of time. Naming who will be plundered does not justify plunder.

title: A Message from Lew Rockwell
description: The Mises Institute’s message has not changed since our founding in 1982. Please join us as we forge ahead, fight for truth, and teach tomorrow’s intellectual leaders.

title: Bernie Sanders and Robert Reich Don't Just Want to Tax the Rich, They Want to Abolish Billionaires
description: The American Left used to argue that we needed higher taxes on the rich so they would "pay their fair share." Nowadays, they are arguing that billionaires shouldn't exist at all.

title: Hazlitt's Critique of Keynes: The 60th Anniversary
description: Hazlitt and all of the other critics of Keynes never did get to the primary points with respect to what was wrong with Keynes. One point was theoretical. The other was practical.

title: Failing to Emigrate Does Not Mean You Give Consent to the State
description: State agents are wrong when they claim, "If you stay here, you must follow our rules. If you do follow our rules, you have tacitly consented to obey us."

title: Why So Many Scholars Are Wrong About Consumer Psychology
description: The idea that people are driven by fear of losses more than they are by the potential for gain has attained a sort of dogmatic adherence among behavioral economists. But there's a problem: the theory isn't true.

title: Paul Volcker: The Man Who Vanquished Gold
description: Mr. Volcker certainly deserves credit for curbing the Great Inflation of the 1970s. However, he also merits a lion’s share of the blame for unleashing the Great Inflation on the US and the world economy in the first place.

title: Good Economic Theory Focuses on Explanation, Not Prediction
description: Many modern economists think the standard for a "good" economic theory is how well it predicts future trends. Not only are most economists terrible at making predictions, but the whole premise of economics as being about predicting things is a flawed idea.

title: A Desperate ECB Wants to Eliminate the Eurozone's "Only Saving Grace"
description: The budgetary restraints that the eurozone placed on member states are now in the crosshairs of ECB President Christine Lagarde.

title: How Unions Reduce Real Wages
description: The actual policies that labor unions have systematically followed from the beginning of their existence have in fact reduced the real wages of the workers as a whole below what they would otherwise have been.

title: How Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren Are Channeling Venezuela's Hugo Chávez
description: That so many voters, pundits, academics, and media figures are taken in by the Warren-Sanders wealth confiscation and redistribution schemes does not bode well for our economic and political future.

title: Chile's Economic Model Is a Success Story in Crisis-Prone South America
description: Since 1975, Chile’s per capita income has increased  fourfold, making it Latin America’s most prosperous country today.

title: The Economic Consequences of the Peace: 100 Years Later
description: John Maynard Keynes's stance on German reparations in the wake of the First World War may have precipitated the rise of Hitler.

title: The Disaster of Zimbabwe's Price Controls
description: Zimbabwe's government has embraced a potent mixture of monetary inflation and price controls. The result has been economic disaster.

title: Where's the Inflation? It's in Stocks, Real Estate, and Higher Ed
description: Price inflation is probably down in energy, food, and apparel. But asset price inflation in stocks and real estate is significant.  This means high rents and high home prices for ordinary people.

title: The US Economy Is Being Japanified — Thanks to the Fed
description: Central bankers are increasingly talking about raising the inflation target above 2 percent. Are negative interest rates next?

title: Medicare and Medicaid Destroyed Healthcare
description: Medicare and Medicaid ended up destroying the finest healthcare system in history, and the healthcare crisis has become a permanent part of American life.

title: Is 150 Years of Bank Credit Expansion Nearing Its End?
description: Central bankers want to find a means of resetting everything, exploring solutions such as digitising currency through blockchains, doing away with cash, and finding other avenues to try to control the so-called vagaries of free markets.

title: Violence, Homesteading, and the Origins of Private Property
description: Even if we find that property was privatized by violence back in the mists of the past, it is not the slightest proof that the abolition of ownership is necessary, advisable, or morally justified.

title: Get Your Free Book Today!
description: Donate today and get your copy!

title: Why the Courts Aren't All They're Supposed to Be
description: The government accepts no legal obligation to provide specified law enforcement services in exchange for the taxes it forcibly extracts from the citizenry. A clearly defined and voluntarily accepted reciprocal agreement between the government and the citizens has never existed.

title: Embrace Unilateral Free Trade with the UK — Right Now
description: Americans ought to begin thinking of trade between the US and the UK as something comparable to trade between California and Idaho.

title: Teacher Unions Destroy School Accountability
description: The Clark County School District evaluated itself, and it determined that all the teachers and administrators are doing a great job — and by the way, the union deserves more money.

title: The Silicon Valley Gulag
description: In his new book Google Archipelago, Rectenwald asserts the Google Archipelago re-upping of Marx is not only practically Marxist, but conceptually and structurally so.

title: The Japanization of the European Union
description: Japan's once-envied economy is now in shambles. The European economy, built on the same shaky tenets, is crumbling, too. Where to go from here?

title: A History of Inflationary Money: From 1844 to Nixon
description: It is a huge mistake to call the repeating cycle of boom and bust a business cycle. That name implies the bust is the failure of markets and capitalism. But it is really due to monetary and credit inflation licensed and promoted by governments and central banks.

title: Why Central Banks Aren't Really Setting Interest Rates
description: Central banks can only distort and mask real interest rates with monetary policy. Interest rates are really set by each individual's time preference.

title: Chilean Protesters Could End Chile's Decades of Progress
description: The history of Latin America is filled with tragic stories of countries reaching great heights — Argentina and Venezuela come to mind — and then falling back to mediocrity. Chile could be next if the protesters get their way.

title: Central Banks May Be Driving Us Toward More Waste, More Carbon Emissions
description: Easy-money policies pushed by central banks may be redirecting wealth away from investment, and toward greater production and consumption of cheap consumer goods. That's not "green."

title: The Woke Media: Apologists for the State
description: Woke journalists are not barriers to state-sponsored oppression, but rather its enablers.

title: Socialism and the Green New Deal: Choose One
description: Central planners cannot calculate the costs and benefits of environmental policy.

title: When the Communists Abolished the Weekend
description: By abolishing the weekend, the Soviets were in one move able to strike a blow against both families and religious institutions. All that was left was the state — and state-mandated labor.

title: Don't Thank Government Officials for Progress in Sanitation and Life Expectancy
description: Government officials have often stood in the way of scientific progress.

title: Easy-Money Policies Don't Solve the Problem of Idle Resources
description: Loose monetary policy can get people to use idle resources. But this new economic activity will likely be in the service of bubble industries that don't create real wealth. Moreover, these bubbles create many idle resources of their own when the bust comes.

title: Why this Boom Could Keep Going Well Beyond 2019
description: As long as there is still room for pushing the market interest rate down even further, the chances are reasonably good that the boom continues, and that the bust will be postponed into the future.

title: How California's Government Plans to Make Wildfires Even Worse
description: The State of California is now forcing insurance companies to cover homeowners who put their houses in some of the most fire-prone areas. What could go wrong?

title: The Communism of Broadway and Hollywood
description: It is noteworthy to remember that no other American milieu was more enthusiastic in the endorsement of communism than that of Hollywood.

title: America’s Arms Sales Addiction
description: Despite its supposedly strained relationship with the Saudi regime, the Obama administration, for example, still managed to offer the royals of that kingdom a record $136 billion  in US weapons between 2009 and 2017.

title: My Path to the Austrian School of Economics
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics
description: There is no more stopping the Mises School. And when the truth finally wins out, because only what is true can also work smoothly in the long run, then the hour of the Austrian School of Economics will have come.

title: Democracy Is Coercive, No Matter What "Civic Republicans" Say
description: For an advocate of civil republicanism, you could be drafted into the army, or taxed at very high rates, and that's fine because you participated in a process (democracy) in which you helped pick your own rulers. This view of freedom has a few problems.

title: Serving the Consumer: The Secret to Walt Disney's Success
description: Had consumers in 1938 been uninterested in a feature-length cartoon, Snow White would have bankrupted the Disney studio. Instead, Walt Disney was richly rewarded for his risk-taking.

title: Abenomics has Failed Japan. Financial Times Wants to Make it Global.
description: The true lesson from Japan is that central planners prefer to gradually nationalize the economy before even considering a moderate reduction in government size and control.

title: We Don't Need Sunday "Blue Laws"
description: Advocates for "blue laws" want to impose more laws on shopkeepers. These moral crusaders should instead start by setting a good example, and stop watching football games, ordering pizzas, or filling up on gas on Sunday.

title: The Benefits of Free Trade Are Canceled Out by Domestic Interventionism
description: Trade agreements have thus become obsolete tokens of negotiation in larger geopolitical disputes, protectionist tools for managing and interfering with global trade flows.

title: China's Mercantilism Is a Recipe for Stagnation
description: China is not on track to catch up with the wealthy West. The Chinese state's commitment to highly interventionist mercantilist policies is leading to debt, malinvestment, and stagnation.

title: How to Avoid Civil War: Decentralization, Nullification, Secession
description: So long as we insist the federal government can force one law, one culture, and one sort of politics on all of America, the US is headed down the road of civil war. Only decentralization and separation can partly defuse the situation.

title: What Venezuela Needs for a Prosperous Future
description: Political and economic salvation for Venezuela can come only from the Venezuelan people themselves. They cannot be “forced to be free.”

title: The ABC of a Market Economy
description: This immense cooperative system is known as a free-market economy. It was not consciously planned by anybody. It evolved.

title: Understanding Elizabeth Warren's "Radical" Wealth Tax
description: Elizabeth Warren’s proposed wealth taxes will have devastating consequences on capital formation, and will encourage investors to hold riskier assets than they otherwise would have.

title: The Washington Post's Double Standard on Immigration and Guns
description: The Washington Post supports local governments ignoring laws. Except when those laws restrict private gun ownership.

title: Anti-Market Conservatives Want to Fix Social Ills, But Their Cure Will Only Make Things Worse
description: Far from being the saviors of society, the new breed of anti-market conservatives are merely the newest iteration of the long line of anti-social apologists for state domination.

title: Exports: Currency Devaluation Won't Grow the Economy
description: When governments devalue the currency to push more exports, the country is getting rich in terms of foreign currency, but it is getting poor in terms of real wealth.

title: Rationality in the Real World Isn't What Economists Think It Is
description: The world doesn't follow predictable patterns based on averages of long-term probability. Ordinary people apparently know this better than statisticians do.

title: Some Fundamental Differences between Ludwig von Mises and Nassim Taleb
description: Taleb maintains he’s a statistically-oriented orthodox economist. But I don’t think he understands what people mean by “orthodoxy.”

title: Central Bankers Have Declared War on Your Savings
description: Negative rates, higher taxes, and inflation – the statists are employing every measure to gain access to the fruits of your labor.

title: John Rawls's Unfortunate Notions of the Nation-State
description: John Rawls claimed "justice" demands governments use their power to benefit the least well off in a given society. But then he arbitrarily restricts the scope of these programs to particular nation-states. This betrays a fundamental problem with his idea of inequality.

title: Social Justice Is Nothing like Real Justice
description: Since no specific victim and no specific crime has been identified, this is no case of reparation as exists under real justice. It is simply a transfer of wealth from one group to another based on some sort of general "exploitation."

title: How Entrepreneurs Learn from the Marketplace
description: In a world of demanding and ever-changing consumers, there is always a way to do things better, with greater quality, and at a lower price. Entrepreneurs must learn how to do this, or they will lose out to those who can.

title: When Nassim Taleb Channels Ludwig von Mises
description: Jeff Deist pithily describes Taleb’s prose as “Rothbard meets Hayek.” But Taleb shares some ideas in common with Ludwig von Mises as well.

title: Private Ownership: A Must
description: If capitalism did not exist, it would be necessary to invent it — and its discovery would be rightly regarded as one of the great triumphs of the human mind.

title: Politicians Want Thanksgiving To Be Political. Ignore Them.
description: Thanksgiving started out as a terribly political holiday. But it has gotten better with age as more people have been interested in beer and football than in politics.

title: The Berlin Wall: Doomed by Economics
description: The Soviets, the Nazis, the Khmer Rouge — these totalitarian regimes would have failed even without any intervention from geopolitical rivals. The socialist systems would have been conquered not by standing armies, but by economics.

title: The Hidden Link Between Fiat Money and the Increasing Appeal of Socialism
description: The psychological impact of a lifetime within a fiat money economy cannot be underestimated. With more wealth seemingly available at the click of a computer button, refusal to spend more on government programs must stem only from cruelty and greed.

title: Maternal Care Scandal in Britain’s NHS Reveals Human Costs of Socialised Medicine
description: In a sense, it is hardly surprising that so little attention has been paid to scandals within universal healthcare systems given the histories of underperformance, scandal, and perpetual crisis associated with many such systems.

title: Capital Accumulation, Not Government, Is the Key To Technological Innovation
description: The diversion of real funding from the private sector toward government projects — no matter how important these projects appear to be — in fact, disrupts the process of real wealth generation.

title: Second Amendment Sanctuaries: Rhetoric vs. Reality
description: Most of the resolutions passed by local governments in the name of "second amendment sanctuary" efforts don't actually do anything.

title: Sound Money Is Our Best Hope Against the Monopolists' Threat
description: Inflationary monetary policy is driving markets toward ever larger and more monopolistic firms that dominate the marketplace.

title: Money-Supply Growth Accelerates to 28-Month High
description: During October 2019, year-over-year growth in the money supply was at 4.95 percent. That's up from September's rate of 3.10 percent, and was up from October 2018's rate of 3.49 percent.

title: Expect the ECB to Use a "Climate Crisis" to Justify Their Next Stimulus Plan
description: The ECB, always happy to repeat the mistakes of Japan, is likely to start new programs of debt monetization for green projects and claim it is a different, radical and new measure.

title: The Nobel Laureates Are Wrong: Of Course Financial Incentives Matter
description: There is a growing drumbeat from some high-profile economists to reassure Americans that large increases in income and wealth taxes won’t distort labor markets. Yet much of their arguments are very misleading.

title: Why Behavioral Economics Isn't Very Useful
description: Behavioral economists are masters of comparing apples to oranges and dressing up incorrect statements in fancy language and mathematics.

title: Why Behavioral Economics Isn't Very Useful
description: Behavioral economists are masters of comparing apples to oranges and dressing up incorrect statements in fancy language and mathematics.

title: A Problem with Paternalism
description: Paternalism has in recent years made a comeback, but its philosophical foundation is quite flimsy.

title: The Dark Side of the American Dream
description: Paul Cantor's new book provides a new look at how the "American dream" is shown in pop culture as offering both hope and frustration.

title: 6 Reasons Why the Most Hated Politician in Latin America Became President of Brazil
description: For many Brazilian voters, Jair Bolsonaro offered a chance to break with decades of failed economic policies. Time will tell if they were right.

title: Freedom Means a Right to Discriminate
description: To prohibit discrimination in employment is to infringe upon freedom of association, freedom of thought, private property, and freedom in general.

title: The Instability of Markets Is Not Nearly as Bad as the Instability of Government Policy
description: Many advocates claim government intervention is necessary because markets are too unstable. The real instability, however, comes from the immense uncertainty over what government will do next with its vast and arbitrary power.

title: Conservatism: A Vanishing Tradition
description: Today's neoconservatives have found common cause with the Left in destroying those who disagree with them. In fact, this habit of denying a forum to any and all dissenters has a long tradition in the conservative movement.

title: Austrian Economics Looks East
description: It is up to us to reconsider Misesian liberal nationalism for the twenty-first century and create a vision for the present and beyond.

title: The Deep State: The Headless Fourth Branch of Government
description: School children learn that there are three branches of government. In actual practice, there is a fourth branch, the permanent bureaucracy which includes legions of civilian and military agents, officers, and administrators committed to protecting their own interests.

title: Don't Want a Liquidity Trap? More Saving Is the Answer
description: The fact that central bank policies become ineffective in reviving the economy is not due to the liquidity trap, but because of the decline in the pool of real savings. This decline emerges due to loose monetary and fiscal policies.

title: Argentina's Destructive Cycle of Economic Populism
description: Anti-market activists in Argentina try to blame the country's economic woes on markets, but the populist movement of Peronism is what has doomed the country to endless cycles of economic and monetary crises.

title: Globalist-Endorsed War on Cash May Be China's Next Terrifying Weapon
description: Transitioning to a cashless society is a natural fit for the authoritarian regime in Beijing — and one that has long been sold as “benign” by the more “liberal” globalist elite.

title: WeWork's IPO Disaster and the Problem of Easy Money
description: When operating in an easy money regime, finding investments capable of providing reasonable returns becomes difficult to near impossible. Low risk vehicles are bid down to near-zero returns, pushing investors into ever riskier vehicles to generate enough return to cover objectives.

title: QE by Any Other Name
description: The Fed overestimated the robustness of the economy, underestimated the level of addiction of the markets to cheap money, and it was way too quick to proclaim a “full recovery” from the crisis.

title: China's Growing Real Estate Bubble
description: Thanks to huge amounts of fiscal and monetary stimulus, China is in the midst of a very large housing bubble, with predictable results for housing affordability.

title: Don't Trust the Government with Breathalyzers and other Forensic Evidence
description: Government police, analysts, and lab workers have been repeatedly shown using faulty technology, forging documents, and falsifying lab results to arrest, prosecute, and convict innocent citizens.

title: Intellectual Property as the New Guild System
description: Even if one strongly believes that IP laws are essential for creativity, it is difficult to justify the expansion of IP protections that have taken place in recent decades.

title: Yes, Taxation Is Theft
description: The government may claim that it needs the funds to provide essential social services: are the poor to be left to starve? But these assertions do not justify its policy of forcible seizure.

title: Defining Poverty
description: One of the great problems involved in setting a standard of poverty is the ever-changing concept of "adequate" nutrition. Recently a nutrition survey concluded that "only one person in a thousand escapes malnutrition!"

title: The West Was Never Really an Enemy of Soviet Communism
description: In his new book Judgment in Moscow, Vladimir Bukovsky claims the spirit of the Bolsheviks was never really destroyed. And it has been kept alive with Western help.

title: It's Trump vs. the Deep State vs. the Rest of Us
description: Even The New York Times now admits there is a deep state — and that it serves its own agenda while ignoring the elected civilian government.

title: Keynes on Eugenics, Race, and Population Control
description: Keynes's Malthusianism indicates that he had a defective understanding of the division of labor and the law of returns. Beyond that, his population policies reveal the totalitarianism inherent in the Keynesian vision.

title: Budget Deficits, not "Neoliberalism," Are To Blame for Argentina’s Crisis
description: Socialists contend that Argentina's economic woes were caused by too much "neoliberalism." Yet not even Argentina's alleged neoliberal president Macri did anything to implement any significant reforms in the direction of free markets.

title: The Case for Free-Market Liberalism in Africa
description: The African continent is exceedingly rich in natural resources, yet the living standard of Africans is very low. The most plausible explanation for this discrepancy is the lack of a system that protects private property.

title: Why Friedman Is Wrong on the Business Cycle
description: A common view is the bust is caused by various mysterious factors that have nothing to do with the previous boom. But that the main problem with Friedman’s model is the lack of a coherent definition of what a boom-bust cycle really is.

title: After Years of Decline, Competition in Banking Finally Grows Again
description: As government-created barriers to entry rise and fall, so does competition in the banking sector.

title: The FDA Wants to Control Your Stem Cells
description: Our right to privacy is premised upon the idea of personal autonomy and extends to the right to bodily integrity. This includes our stem cells.

title: My First Time to East Berlin
description: One East Berliner told me there was not much difference between “freedom” in West and East Berlin because some workers in West Berlin had to commute more than half an hour by bus to get to work.   Hence, they had no freedom.

title: Argentina Votes for More Inflation, Spending, and Economic Instability
description: Argentinians have voted again for the policies that led to the 2014 financial crisis, and many crises before it. The regime remains inflationary and committed to big spending.

title: 19th-Century Americans Didn't "Support the Troops"
description: In the 19th century, the common view of federal soldiers was "as slackers on the public dole" and people with "such a lazy life," as to be "certainly not worth their country's crying about."

title: The Cost of Government Is Rising Much Faster than Housing and Healthcare
description: The American cost of living is driven up not only by housing and healthcare costs, but by even larger increases in tax bills and government spending.

title: Why Government Should Not Fight Deflation
description: The fewer non-productive bubble activities we have, the better it is for those activities that actually crate wealth. But attempts to reverse deflation with new money creation only create new bubbles.

title: 4 Reasons Why Socialism Is Becoming More Popular
description: When it comes to addressing the popularization of socialism, the radicalization of academia is the lynchpin issue. If we could succeed in reversing that tsunami, many dominoes would fall.

title: The Berlin Wall Reminds Us of What Happens After We "Smash Capitalism"
description: It's not necessary to completely destroy capitalism to impoverish us irrevocably. The further a regime moves in the direction of the "egalitarian" states of the old communist world, the worse the impoverishment will be.

title: Locke vs. Cohen  vs. Rothbard on Homesteading
description: Marxist G.A. Cohen is troubled by the freedom libertarians grant to property owners. But artificial limits are unnecessary when practical realities have so often intervened to limit property ownership by any one person.

title: Ocasio-Cortez is Wrong: We're Not Working 80-Hour Weeks Now
description: Some politicians are sure that even average Americans are working more grueling hours than ever. On average we have more leisure time than ever now, and working hours are down over the past 20 years.

title: Austrian Student Scholars Conference, Feb. 21-22, 2020
description: Cash prizes of $1,500, $1,000, and $500 will be awarded to the top three papers.

title: Can Crypto Revive Swiss Banking?
description: While some governments have sought to wage war against cryptocurrencies, Switzerland is striving to become a "crypto-nation."

title: As Gun Owners Look to Nullify Gun Laws, "Sanctuary" Isn't Just for Immigrants
description: From Oregon to Rhode Island, counties and municipalities have announced they will not enforce various state and federal gun laws.

title: The Problem of Poverty
description: The history of poverty is almost the history of mankind. The ancient writers have left us few specific accounts of it because they took it for granted. It was the normal lot.

title: Does Milton Friedman's "Plucking Model" Refute Austrian Business Cycle Theory?
description: Noah Smith's Bloomberg column praises Milton Friedman's "plucking model" of recessions, where the severity of a bust is connected to the strength of the following recovery. Does this refute Mises' BOOM-BUST theory?

title: The IMF Wants the World to Embrace Sweden's Ineffective Carbon Tax
description: Despite the IMF’s claims to the contrary, the case of Sweden actually shows that a political “solution” to climate change is ineffective.

description: As the government continues to pile up trillion dollar deficits, when interest rates return to a historical norm, interest payments on the national debt may exceed payments to Social Security recipients.

title: The Austrian Entrepreneur Versus the Romanticized Entrepreneur

title: The Bank of Japan Shrinks the Pocket Money of Japanese ‘Salarymen’
description: Abenomics, Japanese Keynesianism on steroids, has made the rich richer, and all others poorer.

title: The American Middle Class Isn't Disappearing — But it's Not All Good News
description: Middle-income households and workers haven't been disappearing. They've been moving into higher income levels, while the lowest-income groups have been getting smaller. But another recession could erase many of the gains made over 20 years.

title: The Economics and Politics of Zoning
description: The whole point of zoning is to limit freedom in the development of new housing options. As a result, housing is more expensive, and the consumers are more poorly served.

title: The Fight Against  "Home Sharing" Drives up the Price of Short-Term Housing
description: A lobbying group in Canada is demanding home-sharing services like Airbnb face stiffer government regulation. Activists claims its all for "the community." But huge corporate hotel firms are the only ones likely to really benefit.

title: How School Districts Put Politics Before Children
description: School boards are political institutions often more interested in social policy than in education.

description: Socialism was sold to Africans as the antidote to the legacy of colonial occupiers. But it was the African countries that most resisted socialism that experienced the greatest gains in standards of living.

title: The Power of Self-Ownership
description: Bodily integrity and self-ownership supplement each other: they do not compete for our allegiance.

description: There's nothing necessarily wrong with social shunning and ostracization used against those who seek to destroy others through lies and media manipulation.

description: The reason PG&E can get away with such outrageous mismanagement is that the California government literally guarantees them their business.

description: What would Mises think about the current state of the liberal project he laid out 100 years ago?

title: The Limits of Social Spending as a Driver of Economic Equality
description: The more widespread social programs become, the more they tend to undermine the social interactions and exchanges necessary to build wealth.

description: When asked why they do not just give their money away voluntarily, some billionaires suddenly decide cooperation isn't all that great after all.

description: Poor incentives create poor outcomes, and government subsidies for higher education institutions have created poor incentives in spades.

description: Politicians, who claim that a week in politics is the long term, fail to see any problem.

title: More Government Spending Won't Make the Economy Grow
description: Economic growth comes from the accumulation of real wealth — which is necessary to produce more goods and services.

title: South Africa’s Race-Based Socialism
description: The net effects of the regime's economic planning is wealth destruction and perpetuation of chronic, widespread poverty. South Africa’s per capita GDP, at around $6,000 in 2019, has not increased in inflation-adjusted terms in a quarter-century.

title: Why Austrian School Economists Have a Better Understanding of Goods and Services
description: What makes a good a good is not the physical thing itself, but the value we find in it because it is serviceable toward some valued end.

description: From the beginning, the “97% consensus” claim about climate change has been dubious, with supporters claiming that it represented much more than it really did.

description: A return to a system of 100% bank reserves is anything but radical. It would be quite conservative, prudent, and sensible.

description: Although Argentinians mean well, they cannot seem to break free of an endless loop of crises causes by expansions of the welfare state and deficit spending.

description: EU politicians and technocrats like to present themselves as progressive and enlightened policymakers. But that virtuous mask slipped after German auto giant Volkswagen announced that its new facility would be located in Turkey instead of an EU member nation.

description: The SJWs protesting the so-called "tampon tax" are doing so for rather questionable reasons. But if they're going to argue that taxes are a bad thing, we shouldn't stop them.

title: All Human Beings — Not Just Capitalists — Are Self-Interested
description: Economists don't claim that self-interest is a moral good. They simply recognize it's an important part of human nature, and that government and social institutions must be designed for the human beings that actually exist — callous self-interest and all.

description: When entrepreneurs create profit, we know they are using resources in a way that benefit others. When entrepreneurs causes losses, they are destroying wealth.

description: The string of spending increases announced daily in Europe disguise an extremely dangerous bet: that the ECB will bail out the eurozone forever.

description: Elizabeth Warren's wealth tax is based on the idea that the government knows how to use wealth better than the private sector. The plan also ignores that the wealthy have been shown to flee countries with a wealth tax.

description: Free-market economists don't run the world, and book reviewers at the NYT should stop pretending they do.

title: The Late Great State of California
description: California is now the most taxed and regulated state in the nation. Not surprisingly, life here is becoming less affordable, and less profitable.

title: What if the Majority Voted for “None of the Above”?

title: Stimulus Brings Stagnation: The Case of Japan

title: If People Can't Be Trusted with Market Freedom, They Also Can't Be Trusted with the Vote
description: Behavioral economists say that since individuals are irrational, we need more state intervention in the economy. However, their criticism can be turned around: if individuals are irrational, government power is especially dangerous.

title: Bernie Sanders is a Bad Economist: Housing Market Edition
description: Bernie Sanders's proposed "House Fixing tax" would not only hurt flippers and their homebuying customers but also some landlords and tenants as well.

title: New Nobel Winners Are Latest Bad Sign for Economic Theory

title: New Nobel Winners Are Latest Bad Sign for Economic Theory
description: The economist’s task is not to demonstrate (empirically) that x is associated with y, but to provide a causal explanation of how x affects y.

title: What We Can Learn from Indian Tribes on Immigration
description: If we grant that Indian tribes ought to be able to restrict membership (i.e., naturalization) for their own groups, on what principle can this be denied to other groups?

description: Environmentalists rightly point out it is very difficult to manage a complex ecosystem. But they conveniently ignore the fact it's even more difficult to manage an economic system — especially one thrown into disarray by environmental regulations.

title: Politics Drops Its Pretenses
description: We need an anti-politics movement just as surely as we need an antiwar movement.

description: Local governments think the key to "smart" downtown development is to restrict parking, and force people to take a bus. In reality, people just decide to avoid downtown, thwarting efforts at development.

title: How Entrepreneurs Discover Market Opportunities Through Dissatisfaction
description: Entrepreneurs try to find gaps in the marketplace where consumers are not quite satisfied with the status quo. Successful entrepreneurs then fill in those gaps.

title: When Conservatives Denounced Freedom as "Unpatriotic"
description: Conservatives tell us that we must move beyond the idea of allowing people to trade freely in the marketplace. "Patriotism" is the true measure of economic policy, and that requires higher taxes, more government spending, and a powerful state.

title: Have Free-Market Economists Conquered the World?
description: Both left and right now repeatedly push a myth: the myth that governments have been taken over by laissez-faire hard-core free-market economists who have turned the world into a landscape of untrammeled capitalism.

title: Why "Worker Exploitation" Is a Myth
description: Workers get paid now, but the capitalists only get paid if there is a profit. This is why workers aren't paid 100 percent of the value of their output. For them, there is far less risk than for the capitalist.

title: The Mythology of the "Natural Interest Rate"
description: Central bankers are claiming that a global savings glut is driving down the "natural" interest rate to negative levels. They're wrong.

title: The Ghosts of Failed Banks Have Returned
description: A new banking crisis is not only in the making, for which the repo problem serves as an early warning, but it could escalate quite rapidly.

title: The World's Least-Free Countries Reveal Just How Much "Socialism Sucks"
description: When socialists held up Venezuela in the 2000s, the message was, ‘See, we told you so; socialism works!’ but when failure happened, the message changed to, “No, wait — that’s not real socialism!’

title: Central Banks Are Just Getting Warmed Up
description: Central Banks now have an alphabet soup of policy tools. But it's all radlly just more of the same — that is, inflationary easy-money monetary policy.

title: Shays's Rebellion: The Excuse for a Centralized American State
description: The so-called Founding Fathers used small-scale tax rebellions to justify their counter-revolution against the spirit of 1776, thus launching the big-tax, big-government Constitutional Convention of 1787.

title: The Repo Crisis Shows the Damage Done by Central Bank Policies
description: The repo crisis — and it is a crisis — is telling us that liquidity providers are aware that the price of money, the assets used as collateral and the borrowers’ ability to repay are all artificially manipulated.

title: Austrian School vs. “Law & Economics" on Product Safety
description: A look at the differences between the Austrian School and the "Law & Economics" tradition, with respect to product safety regulation.

title: Paleolithic People Were Not Primitive Communists
description: Assuming that some groups of foragers indeed practiced "primitive communism," they would have died out because they had lost the fierce competition with the more economically viable "libertarian" tribes. Communism has never appeared spontaneously and "naturally" in the history of mankind.

title: The Conservative Attack on Market Freedom
description: Many conservatives seem to believe that America has been taken over by hard-core libertarians, with the result being a dystopian plutocracy. The answer, they tell us, lies in high taxes and more government power.  They're wrong about both the diagnosis and the cure.

title: Wilhelm Roepke, RIP
tags: History of the Austrian School of Economics,
description: In the midst of moral and intellectual decay, Roepke was an inflexible harbinger of the return to reason, honesty and sound political practice.

title: The Hidden Costs of a Universal Basic Income
description: Supporters of the universal basic income claim it ends dependence on markets, bosses, family, and bureaucrats. But it doesn't eliminate dependence. It only transfers dependence to the central state.

title: A Fact About Profits That's Almost Totally Ignored
description: Profits are sales minus costs.

title: Reduced Sentences in Exchange for Lies: A Government Tradition
description: Governments routinely bribe suspects into accusing others in exchange for reduced sentences. Thus, suspects are willing to say pretty much anything prosecutors want them to. Governments are fine with this.

title: The Return of Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe
description: As Zimbabwe's economy worsens, its government now insists residents start using easily-inflated local currency again. This is sowing the seed of another devastating episode of hyperinflation.

title: China Should Still Be Celebrating the End of Mao's Communism
description: As it celebrates 70 years of the "People's Republic," China shouldn't forget its rise was made possible by its turn away from communism.

title: Taking a Stand for "the People" Usually Means Hurting Actual People
description: Tucker Carlson insists that capitalism is just a "tool" that governments can regulate and manipulate so as to better serve "the people." In practice, this just means one group of "the people" uses government policy to enrich themselves at the expense of others.

title: Not-So-Modern Monetary Theory
description: MMT “is a mix of old and new, the old is correct and well understood, while the new is substantially wrong.”

title: Socialism Is the Greatest Threat to the Environment
description: There are only two ways to solve environmental challenges: competition and technology. That requires capitalism, not the government.

title: Economic Growth Does Not Cause Price Inflation
description: It is not true that a growing economy will lead to price inflation. A growing economy is an increasingly productive economy and leads to dollars chasing a larger number of goods and services — causing deflation.

title: Government Meddling Is the Reason You're "Underpaid"
description: It is frequently allege that, under capitalism, people aren’t paid what they are worth to employers. But the commonly-drawn implication that state intervention will improve things is false.

title: The Economics of Prison Gangs

title: Are Entrepreneurs Born or Made?
description: In The Free Market and Its Enemies, Mises wrote, “Even though you know everything about the past, you know nothing about the future.” This explains that the timeframe and economic constraints at work are vital to the expression of entrepreneurial talents.

title: No, Capitalism Doesn’t Threaten Humanity
description: Anti-capitalist promoters of "climate justice" ignore all of the evidence of capitalism’s benefits staring us in the face.

title: Beware of Defense Secretaries Pledging Reform

title: Can Spain Handle a Global Crisis?
description: There seems to be an increasing consensus that a global recession is coming soon. The good news is that the Spanish private sector is much better prepared than it was in 2007.

description: Market prices reveal critical information about sellers, buyers, and market demand. But government interference in markets substitutes a fake version of reality that leads to impoverishment.

title: Harry Jaffa, Michael Anton, and Me
description: Harry Jaffa's disciples are rather sensitive to criticism.

title: Argentina's Faux "Neoliberalism"

title: The Difference Between Regulated Markets and Free Markets
description: What exchanges take place, and which do not, is affected by how markets are regulated. Black markets and regulated markets have different outcomes than free markets.

description: Some people — including Donald Trump — think the dollar is too strong, and many propose the creation of a new version of the Plaza Accord, i.e., a multilateral agreement that includes coordinated intervention in foreign exchange markets.

title: The US Dollar Beast
description: Without a turn toward hard money, the odds are that the world’s dependence on the Greenback will not decline but presumably grow even more in the years to come.

title: The State as a Voluntary Institution: A Critique
